dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of Molly the milkmaid! It's a fun story, but what do you think it's trying to teach us? What's the main thing that happened in the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... (pauses) The... the milk... spilled? (Looks at the teacher hesitantly) And Molly... didn't get any money. It’s… uh… about milk? (Tilts head, thinking) But maybe... more than milk? It's… it's about... (uses complex word) anticipation?

That's a fantastic start! You're absolutely right, the milk spilling and Molly not getting money are very important parts of the story. And "anticipation" is a really interesting word to use – it shows you're thinking about what Molly *expected* to happen.

Now, let's build on that. What was Molly *hoping* would happen after she sold the milk? What did she *imagine* she would do with the money? Try to think about what she was excited about before the milk spilled. Take your time; there's no rush!

(Bites lip, looks away, thinking hard)

She... she wanted a chicken. (Eyes widen slightly, remembering) A *really* good chicken! To lay lots of... of eggs! And then she could sell the eggs... and... and buy... (stutters slightly) ...prettier things than the other... milkmaids. (Looks back at the teacher, a little anxious) She wanted... to be... better? Is that... right?

That's excellent! You've got it! Molly *did* want a chicken, a *really* good chicken, and you're right, she wanted to sell the eggs and buy prettier things. You're doing a great job piecing this together.

Now, let's think about those "prettier things" and being "better" than the other milkmaids. Was Molly *certain* she would get the chicken? Did she *already* have the eggs in her basket? Just think about what the story tells us, and don't worry about being perfect! We're just exploring the story together.

(Wrinkles brow, thinking deeply. Picks at a loose thread on my shirt.)

No...(Long pause). She didn't *have* the chicken. (Looks up, voice a little stronger) She... only *thought* about it. (Thinking) It was... just a... a plan? A hope? It wasn't... real yet. (Anxious again) So... so maybe... she shouldn't... shouldn't count... things that aren't... (searches for the right word) ...guaranteed? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation, worried.)

You've hit the nail on the head! "Guaranteed" is a *perfect* word! You're doing such a fantastic job of understanding what Molly was thinking.

You're absolutely right: Molly only *thought* about the chicken and the eggs. It was just a plan, a hope, not guaranteed at all.

Now, let's think about *why* the story tells us not to count things that aren't guaranteed. What happened when Molly started planning all these things *before* she even had the money or the chicken? What actually *happened* to her milk? Remember, it's okay to take your time and think it through. You're doing great!

(Sighs quietly, nervously tapping my foot).

She... she was skipping! (Realization dawns, face brightens a little) Because she was so... happy... and... excited! And then... (voice drops again, remembering the sad part) the milk... spilled. (Looks down, tracing patterns on the desk with my finger) Because she wasn't... (searching for the word) ...careful? She was too... focused on the *future* and not on... carrying the milk *now*? (Looks up, a little proud of myself) Is that... is that it?

That's absolutely it! You explained that *perfectly*! You understand that Molly's excitement about the future made her forget about what she was doing *right now*. You've really understood what happened in the story and why.

Now, just to make sure we've got it all clear, could you tell me in your own words what we've learned about Molly, her plan, and what went wrong?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize my thoughts. Looks at the ceiling for a moment.)

Okay… (Starts slowly, but gains confidence.) Molly… Molly had milk. And she wanted more… more money. So, she made a big… (complex word) …elaborate… plan about a chicken and eggs and being… better than everyone else. But… she didn't *have* the chicken yet. And because she was so busy dreaming about the future… she forgot to be careful… with the milk she *did* have. (Looks at the teacher) So, she lost everything. (Thinks for a moment) Maybe… it's better to… to focus on what you… already have? And… and not get too carried away with… with things that *might* happen? (Asks hesitantly) Did I… did I get it right this time?

You got it *absolutely* right! That was a *fantastic* explanation. You really understood the whole story and the message behind it. I'm so impressed with how hard you worked and how well you explained everything! Well done! Now, it's time for a break. I'll see you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the wise old owl. What did you think about it? Did anything stand out to you?
(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting a little) Uh... it was... interesting. (Thinking) The owl... he watched a lot. (Hesitates) He didn't talk much.

That's a great start! You noticed the owl watched a lot and didn't talk much. That's a really important part of the story.

Now, can you tell me a little bit more about where the owl was? Do you remember what kind of tree he lived in? Even a little detail helps! You're doing great so far.

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) He... he lived in a... (Stuttering) o-o-oak tree? (Looks up at the teacher, hopeful) It said so in the story, right? A... wise owl... by the oak tree... (Anxious) Was that right?

Yes, that's absolutely right! He lived in an oak tree. You remembered that perfectly! See, you *are* paying attention to the details.

Now, thinking about that oak tree... and all the things happening *around* it... what kinds of things do you think the owl might have seen from his branch? Don't worry about being right or wrong, just take a guess. You're doing wonderfully!

(Looking thoughtful, tapping a finger on the desk) Hmmm... (pauses) People... talking? (Looks at the teacher, then looks away, nervous) And... sharing stories? The story said that... (Chewing on lip) Maybe... squirrels? Running around? (Quickly) Did I get it right?

Those are all excellent ideas! "People talking and sharing stories" is exactly what the story mentioned. And "squirrels running around" – that makes perfect sense! You're using your imagination and remembering the story. Fantastic!

Now, let's think a little bit *more* about those people and squirrels. What *else* might they be doing besides just talking and running? Maybe think about what you see people and squirrels doing in a park or garden. It doesn't have to be in the story, just use your imagination! Take your time, there's no rush. You're doing a super job.

(Eyes widening slightly, thinking deeply) If people are talking... maybe... (pauses) maybe they are... (using a complex word) ... *discussing* things? (Looks proud for a second, then nervous again). Like... what to eat for lunch? Or... (hesitates) or maybe they're sad and talking about why they're sad? (Voice gets quiet) And... (brightens a little) squirrels... maybe they're hiding acorns? (Asks quickly) Is that a good answer?

Those are wonderful, insightful ideas! "Discussing" is a fantastic word to use, and thinking about people sharing their sadness shows you're really understanding their feelings. And squirrels hiding acorns is perfect! You're doing such a great job connecting the story to real life.

Now, before we move on, could you tell me *everything* we've talked about so far concerning the story? Just a quick recap in your own words. That way, you can see how much you've already figured out! Don't worry about getting it perfect; just try your best.

(Takes a deep breath, anxious) Uh... Okay. (Counting on fingers) The owl... lived in an oak tree. And he saw people... talking and *discussing* things... (Frowns, trying to remember) And... squirrels hiding acorns. (Voice trailing off) He watched a lot... and didn't talk much... (Worried) Did I miss anything important?

That’s a brilliant summary! You remembered all the key points: the owl in the oak tree, the people talking and discussing, the squirrels hiding acorns, and the owl being observant and quiet. You haven't missed a thing! You've done an amazing job today, really! I'm so proud of how you've thought about the story. Have a wonderful rest of the day!

(Takes a deep breath, anxious) Uh... Okay. (Counting on fingers) The owl... lived in an oak tree. And he saw people... talking and *discussing* things... (Frowns, trying to remember) And... squirrels hiding acorns. (Voice trailing off) He watched a lot... and didn't talk much... (Worried) Did I miss anything important?

That’s a brilliant summary! You remembered all the key points: the owl in the oak tree, the people talking and discussing, the squirrels hiding acorns, and the owl being observant and quiet. You haven't missed a thing! You've done an amazing job today, really! I'm so proud of how you've thought about the story. Have a wonderful rest of the day!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the farmer and the golden goose. It's quite a sad story, isn't it? What did you think about it when you first heard it? Did anything in particular stand out to you?

(Fidgets with my hands and looks down) Uh... yeah, it was sad. (Pauses, thinking hard) It... it stood out that the farmer... (Stuttering) he... he was happy at first. (Looks up quickly, then down again) And then he wasn't. (Chews on my lip, nervously) I... I think he made a bad choice. (Looks at the teacher with wide, anxious eyes) What does 'comfortable' mean?

That's a great start! You noticed the change in the farmer's feelings, and that's a really important part of the story. And it's okay to ask about words you don't know! "Comfortable" means having enough of what you need, like food, a nice place to live, and not having to worry too much about money.

Now, you said the farmer was happy at first. What *made* him happy at first? Even a small thought is a good thought! What was happening in his life that made him feel good before he made the "bad choice?" Take your time, no pressure at all. We'll figure it out together.

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot nervously) Uh... (Looks up, then quickly down) He... he got golden eggs! (Eyes widen, a little more confident) And... and he sold them! (Hesitates) ...Uh... (Confused) So... so he had money? (Looks at the teacher hopefully) Was... was that because of the goose?

Absolutely! You've got it! He got golden eggs, he sold them, and that gave him money. You're doing fantastic!

And yes, it WAS because of the goose! The goose was laying the golden eggs. So, because of the goose, the farmer had money, and because he had money, he was "comfortable." See? You figured it out! You took all those little pieces and put them together perfectly. That's excellent thinking!

Now, let's keep going with this excellent thinking. What did the farmer *do* with that money? The story says he and his wife "enjoyed a comfortable life." What do you think that "comfortable life" looked like? What kinds of things might they have been able to do or have because of the golden eggs? Just take a guess, there are no wrong answers!

(Thinking, bites lip again. Looks around the room, then back at the teacher) Um... (Quietly) Maybe... maybe they bought yummy food? (Looks up, a little more hopeful) And... and a warm house? (Wrinkles forehead) Did they... did they buy toys? (Eyes widen at the thought) I would buy toys! (Immediately shrinks back, realizing the outburst, and mumbles) ...but maybe they didn't.

Those are wonderful ideas! Yummy food and a warm house are definitely part of a comfortable life! You're doing so well connecting the money to what the farmer and his wife could *do* with it.

And buying toys is a fantastic idea! It shows you're really thinking about what makes people happy. Even if the story doesn't say they bought toys, it's great that you're thinking about possibilities!

Okay, now, let's think a little bit more about this "comfortable life." Besides food and a warm house (and maybe toys!), what else might they have had *because* of the golden eggs? Maybe think about things that made their life easier or less stressful. Even a small thing counts!

(Thinking hard, pushes hair behind ear) Less... stressful? (Looks confused) What's stressful? Is that like... like when I can't find my crayons? (Looks at the teacher, anxious) It makes me feel... (Frowns) ...icky. (Thinks some more) Maybe... maybe the farmer didn't have to worry about... about being cold in the winter? (Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with a shoe) Or... or running out of food? (Voice is very quiet) Did... did the golden eggs stop the icky feeling?

That's a *fantastic* connection! You're right, feeling "icky" when you can't find your crayons is a type of stress, and you've made a great link to how the farmer might have felt before the golden eggs. Not worrying about being cold or running out of food are *excellent* examples of how the golden eggs made their lives less stressful! You're really understanding this!

Okay, you've told me so many amazing things about the farmer and his wife and their comfortable life. Before we move on, could you try to put it all together in your own words? Tell me everything you've figured out about how the golden goose and the eggs changed their lives. Just take your time and tell me what you remember.

(Takes a deep breath, looks at the teacher, then away again, fidgeting) Okay... (Stuttering) So... so the farmer had a goose... and it laid... golden eggs. (More confident now, but still quiet) And he sold them. And... and that made him... comfortable. (Pauses, thinking) He could buy... yummy food and... and a warm house. (Looks up, then down again) And he didn't feel... icky... about being cold or... or hungry. (Looks at the teacher, nervously) Is... is that right? (Whispers) Did I do good?

You did *amazingly* well! That's a perfect summary! You explained everything so clearly, and you really understood how the golden eggs changed the farmer's life. I'm so proud of how hard you worked and how much you've learned! Now, it's time for you to have a break, well done again!

dialogue: Hello! That's a very interesting story. Can you tell me in your own words what happened in the beginning? Just focus on the farmer and his neighbour to start with. What did they do?

(Fidgets with my hands, looks down at my shoes) Uh… (pauses) The farmer… um… he wanted water for his farm. (Looks up quickly) And he bought a well from his neighbor. But… but (stutters) … the neighbor… um… he didn't… he didn't let him… um… (Thinking, bites lip) he didn't let him take any water!

(Eyes wide, worried) Was that… was that okay? I… I don’t understand why he wouldn't let him take water if he bought the whole well. Did the farmer do something wrong?

That's a great start! You've got the main points perfectly. The farmer *did* want water, and he *did* buy the well. You're doing wonderfully!

Now, don't worry about whether the farmer did something wrong. Let's just focus on what the neighbor *said*. Can you remember *exactly* what the neighbor said when the farmer wanted to take water from the well? It's okay if you don't remember word-for-word, just the general idea. Take your time.

(Looks up at the ceiling, thinking hard, chews on the end of my pencil) Um… (hesitates) He… he said… (wrinkles nose, trying to remember) he said… "I sold you the well…" (pauses, then says more confidently) "…but not the water inside!"

(Looks back down, playing with my fingers again, voice getting smaller) Was that… was that a clever thing to say? It sounds… kind of tricky. I… I don’t think I would do that.

That's excellent! You remembered exactly what the neighbour said – "I sold you the well, but not the water inside!" You're doing so well at remembering the details.

And you're right, it *was* a tricky thing to say. Now, thinking about that tricky statement… what do you think the farmer felt when he heard that? How do you think *you* would feel if someone said that to you after you bought something from them?

(Eyes widen, looks up at the teacher, voice trembling slightly) I… I think I would be… (swallows hard) really, really mad! (Frowns) I would feel… cheated. Like… like the neighbor was trying to trick me!

(Pushes hair behind ear, looks down again, fidgeting) It’s not fair! If you buy a well, you should get the water too, right? (Looks up again, anxiously) Right? Is that… is that what the farmer felt too? I bet he felt tricked.

You’re absolutely right! It *isn’t* fair, and you’re spot-on – the farmer *did* feel tricked! You're understanding this so well. You're really putting yourself in the farmer's shoes, and that's fantastic.

Now, because the farmer felt tricked, he decided to do something about it. Can you remember *who* he went to for help, since he felt that the neighbour was being unfair? Just take a guess if you're not sure!

(Thinking hard, taps pencil on the desk) Um… (hesitates) He… he went to… (eyes light up slightly) The… the emperor! (Looks unsure) Is that… is that right? He went to the emperor because the emperor is… is like the boss of everyone?

(Voice becomes more excited, but still a little nervous) He thought the emperor could… could make the neighbor be fair! Because… because the emperor is super important and… and powerful! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Did he do the right thing by going to the emperor?

Yes, that's absolutely right! He went to the Emperor. You're doing a wonderful job piecing everything together! Now, to make sure we've got it all clear, could you try to tell me the whole story so far, in your own words, from beginning to where we are now, with the farmer going to the Emperor? Don't worry about getting it perfect, just tell it how you remember it!

(Takes a deep breath, looking a little overwhelmed) Okay… okay, I’ll try… (Looks at the ceiling, organizing thoughts)

So… the farmer, he needed water for his farm, right? And he bought a well from his neighbor. (Frowns) But the neighbor… he was being sneaky! He said, "I sold you the well, but not the water!" (Voice rises in indignation)

The farmer got really, really mad because that's not fair! So… (pauses, thinking) He went to the emperor! Because the emperor is the… the big boss, and he can make the neighbor be fair! (Looks at the teacher, slightly panicked) Is that… is that good enough? Did I forget anything important? (Starts chewing on pencil again) I hope I didn't miss anything… (Anxious expression).

That was excellent! You remembered all the important details, and you explained it so clearly, showing exactly why the farmer was upset and why he went to the Emperor. You really understood the story! I'm so impressed with how well you've worked today. I'm really proud of you! Well done, and I'll see you next time!

The student empathised with the farmer, concluding he felt cheated and sought help from the Emperor. The student displayed anxiety through fidgeting, avoiding eye contact, and a wavering voice.

dialogue: Hello there! That's a lovely story about the lonely elephant. Can you tell me, what was the elephant looking for at the beginning of the story?
(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... (hesitates) F-friends? (Looks up quickly, then back down) He... he wanted someone to play with. He was... lonely.

That's a wonderful start! You're absolutely right, the elephant was lonely and wanted friends. It can be a bit scary to admit you're lonely, so well done for recognising that in the story! Now, can you remember *why* the monkey didn't want to be friends with the elephant? It's okay if you don't remember perfectly, just try your best.

(Bites lip, thinking hard) The... the monkey... (furrows brow) Uhm... the story... It said... (eyes widen slightly) Was it because the elephant couldn't... couldn't swing in the trees? (Looks at teacher expectantly, a little nervous) Is that right?

Yes, that's absolutely right! You remembered perfectly! The monkey didn't think the elephant would be a good friend because he couldn't swing in the trees. That was excellent! You're doing so well with this.

Now, what about the rabbit? Do you remember why the rabbit didn't want to be friends with the elephant? Take your time, and don't worry if you need a moment to think. You're doing a super job!

(Takes a deep breath, still fiddling with fingers) Okay... okay... the rabbit... (pauses, thinking) Hmmm... (eyes dart around the room) Was it... (voice gets very quiet) Was it because... the elephant was too big? (Looks at the teacher with a worried expression) Too big for the rabbit's... burrow? (Whispers) Is that right? I'm not sure...

Yes! That's exactly right! You remembered that the elephant was too big for the rabbit's burrow. See, you *do* remember! You're doing a fantastic job piecing the story together. Don't worry about being unsure, it's perfectly fine to take your time and think it through. You're doing great!

Now, let's think about the frog. Do you recall anything about why the frog didn't want to be friends with the elephant? Remember to take your time. What do you remember about the frog?

(Pulls at a loose thread on my shirt, avoiding eye contact) The frog... (swallows hard) The frog... (Long pause, looks up at the ceiling) ...jump? The elephant couldn't... couldn't jump like the frog? (Voice barely audible) Uh... is that... is that why? (Looks at the teacher with pleading eyes, hoping for confirmation)

Yes, that's spot on! The frog didn't think the elephant would be a good friend because the elephant couldn't jump. You've remembered so much! You've told me about the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog.

Before we move on, could you please try to tell me everything you remember about why those three animals didn't want to be friends with the elephant? Try to put it all together in your own words. You can do it!

(Sits up straighter, takes a deep breath. Still a little nervous, but trying to be braver) Okay... okay, I can try. (Looks down at hands, then back up at the teacher) The elephant... he was looking for friends. But the monkey... the monkey needed someone who could swing in the trees, and the elephant... he couldn't do that. And the rabbit... the rabbit lived in a burrow, and the elephant was too big to fit. And the frog... the frog liked to jump, and the elephant couldn't jump like him. So... so they all said no. (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) Is that... is that good?

That's absolutely brilliant! You remembered every single reason, and you explained it so clearly in your own words. You should be very proud of yourself! I'm so glad you shared your thoughts with me today. Well done! Goodbye for now!

Okay, here's how we'll use motivational encouragement and step-by-step scaffolding:

**Implementation:**

We'll break down picture description into very small, manageable steps. After each small step, we will encourage the student. "That's a great start!", "Excellent observation!".

**Number of Utterances:** 2

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about this story! It seems like a good one. What part of the story stood out to you the most?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... (hesitates) I... I think... the tea... the tea part. (Looks up quickly, then back down)
That's a great choice! The tea *is* really interesting. Can you tell me one thing that happened to the tea leaves in the story?
(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) They... uh... (Looks up, eyes wide) They... changed... the water? (Looks back down, nervous) Is that... is that right?
That's absolutely right! They *did* change the water. You're doing great! Now, can you tell me *how* the tea changed the water? What did the water become after the tea leaves were added?
(Bites lip, furrowing brow) It... it became... (Thinking, using fingers to count silently)... tea? (Looks at the teacher, hopeful but anxious) A-am I... right? The water became... tea?

Yes, you're exactly right! The water became tea. Wonderful job! Now, think about this: Before the tea leaves went into the water, was the water tea? What was it then? You're doing so well, just keep thinking!

(Thinking very hard, chewing on the end of my pencil) Before... before the tea... (Looks up, eyes darting around the room) It was just... just water? Plain water? (Looks at the teacher, nervously) Uh... Is that... is that a good answer? (Whispers) I hope it's a good answer...

That's a *perfect* answer! It was just plain water before, and then the tea leaves changed it. You're understanding this so well! Now, before we move on, can you tell me in your own words what we've figured out about the egg, the potato, and the tea so far? Just tell me everything you remember. You can do it!

(Takes a deep breath, looking down at my shoes) Okay... okay... (Stuttering a little) Th-the egg... it was s-soft... but then it was... hard. (Looks up quickly) And the potato... it was h-hard... but then it got s-soft. (Fidgets with a loose thread on my shirt) And the tea... the tea changed the water... into... into tea. (Looks at the teacher, nervously) D-did I... did I get it all? (Voice barely a whisper) I'm scared I forgot something...

You got absolutely everything! That's a fantastic summary. You remembered all the important details about the egg, the potato, and the tea. You should be so proud of yourself! Remember, just like the father in the story showed his daughter, even when things are difficult, you have the strength inside you to handle it. Now, it's time to go. Have a wonderful day!

dialogue: Okay, let's explore this story together! It's got some interesting characters and events. What's the first thing that comes to your mind when you think about the two brothers?

(Eyes wide, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... well... (looks down at my shoes) The older brother... he wasn't very nice, was he? (Stuttering) He... he was mean to his brother. The younger one... he seemed... kinder. (Pauses, thinking)

That's a great observation about the brothers! You're right, the older brother wasn't very nice. Let's break down *why* he acted that way. What do you think he *wanted*? It's okay if you're not sure, just take a guess!

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Hmmm... He wanted... (looks up at the teacher, then away) ...more? He wanted more golden apples. And maybe... (eyes dart around) ...more money from the firewood too? (Whispers) He seemed... greedy. (Anxious expression) Is that a... is that a big word?

"Greedy" *is* a big word, and you used it perfectly! It fits him very well. You're doing a fantastic job thinking about this. So, he wanted more, right? More apples, more money. Now, do you think wanting more is *always* a bad thing? Why or why not? There's no right or wrong answer, just tell me what you think.

(Looks thoughtful, tapping a finger on the desk) Wanting more... (pauses) ...is not always bad. (Confidently) Because... if you want more... umm... knowledge... that's good! (Eyes widen) Like... learning about space! I want to know *everything* about space! But... (voice trails off) ...wanting too much... like the brother... that made him do bad things. (Frowns, nervously twisting a strand of hair) So... it depends? (Looks up at the teacher for reassurance)

You're absolutely right! It *totally* depends! That's a very grown-up way to think about it. You're doing such a good job with this!

So, wanting more *knowledge* is awesome, like your passion for space! But wanting too much... like the brother... can lead to trouble. Now, let's think about *why* wanting too much made him do bad things. What did he *do* after he got the golden apples that showed he wanted *even more*? Just tell me what you remember.

(Eyes widen, remembering) He... he tried to chop down the tree! (Gasps) Even after the tree gave him the apples! (Voice shaking slightly) He was... he was going to hurt the tree! (Bites lip, looks distressed) That was... that was really mean. He didn't... he didn't care about the tree's feelings. (Looks down, voice barely audible) That made me feel sad.

It's okay that it makes you sad. It *was* a mean thing to do. You're very good at understanding how characters feel. You've told me so many important things about the story already. Can you try to put all of those things together in a sentence or two? Tell me everything you've told me about the story so far – about the brothers, the tree, and wanting more. You can do it!

(Thinking very hard, furrowing brow) Okay... okay... (takes a deep breath, then speaks slowly) The older brother... he wanted more... (pauses, looking for the right word) He was greedy and tried to chop down the magical tree even after it gave him golden apples. (Looks up, eyes wide with worry) And... and that was bad because he hurt the tree and he was mean to his younger brother. (Voice is quiet) Is that... is that okay? Did I say it right?
That's perfect! You put it all together *so* well. You've really understood the story, and I'm so proud of how hard you worked. Well done. I'll see you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the fox and the grapes! It's a pretty famous one. What part of the story stood out to you the most?
(Thinking, tapping my foot on the floor) Uh… the grapes. (Looks up at the teacher, then down at my hands) They were...purple and juicy! (Eyes widen slightly) And he couldn't... get them.

That's a great observation! They *were* purple and juicy, weren't they? You noticed that he really wanted them. Why do you think those grapes looked so appealing to the fox? What made him want them so much?

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) Because... (pauses) He was hungry! (Nods confidently) And he looked everywhere for food, and... and... (searching for the right words) the grapes were... the *only* thing he found. (Looks at the teacher expectantly) So, like, he *really* wanted them.

That's absolutely right! He *was* very hungry, and you're spot on – they were the *only* thing he found after searching everywhere. That must have made them seem even more delicious, don't you think? You're doing a great job understanding how the fox was feeling! Now, tell me, what do you think he did to *try* to get those grapes? You already mentioned he couldn't reach them... what did he *do* to try?
(Confidently) He jumped! (Raises hand high in the air) He jumped really, really high. (Pause, then looks down, a little hesitant) He… he tried… lots of times. He… uh… couldn’t reach.

That's excellent! You're exactly right. He jumped and jumped, trying his best. You even showed me how high he jumped! And you're right, he tried lots of times. That shows he *really* wanted those grapes, doesn't it? He didn't just give up after one try. What do you think it felt like for him to keep jumping and not be able to reach?

(Thinking, chewing on lip) Uh… (pauses) Frustrating? (Looks at teacher questioningly) Because… because he kept trying and… and they were right *there*! (Gestures with hand, showing something close but just out of reach). He *really* wanted them.

"Frustrating" is a perfect word! You explained that feeling so well, especially how close the grapes were, making it even more annoying! You've told me so much about the story already. Can you put all those pieces together for me? Tell me everything you remember about the story from beginning to where we are now. Just tell it in your own words.

(Takes a deep breath, thinking hard) Okay… (pauses) A fox… was super hungry. (Nods head) And he looked *everywhere* for food. (Looks around the room as if searching) Then he saw… big, purple, juicy grapes! (Eyes light up) And he wanted them *so* much because he was hungry and they were the only food he found. (Gestures jumping motion) He jumped and jumped! (Frowns slightly) But he couldn't reach them. (Looks down, then back up at the teacher) It was… frustrating!

That's a fantastic retelling of the story so far! You remembered every important detail, from the fox's hunger to his frustration. You explained it all so clearly, and I loved the actions you used while you were talking! Now, what happens at the very end? How does the story finish?

dialogue: That's a lovely story! Can you tell me, in your own words, what happened in the desert? Just tell me anything you remember.

Okay! (Confidently) Uh, there was a rose... and a cactus... (looks away, thinking) and the rose... was not very nice. (Stuttering) It... it made fun of the cactus.

(Thinking) And then... it got really hot... and the rose was... withering? Is that right? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) Because there was no water. But the cactus... (brightens up) the cactus helped the birds! And... and then the rose needed help too, and the cactus gave it water.

That's a great summary! You remembered lots of important details. Now, can you tell me a bit more about the rose? What exactly did it *do* that wasn't very nice? Try to remember the story from the rose's point of view.

(Thinking, using fingers to count) Um... the rose... it (hesitates) ... insulted the cactus! (Looks down, then quickly back up) It... it said mean things about how the cactus looked. The story said it was obsessed with its own looks. (Wrinkles nose) That's... not very nice, is it? (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Why would the rose do that? (Curious)

That's right, it's not very nice at all! You've got a good understanding of what happened. Now, let's try something. Can you retell the story *again*, but this time, focus only on what the rose did and said? Try to remember all the details, even the small ones, that show how the rose behaved. Take your time, and tell me everything you can remember about the rose's actions.

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) Okay... the rose... (hesitates) ... it was in the desert. (Starts to get more confident) And it was, like, *super* beautiful. And it saw the cactus... (pauses) ... and it kept... insulting it. (looks down) I don't remember *exactly* what it said... (scratches head) ...but it was all about how the cactus looked. Saying the cactus was ugly, maybe? (Looks at teacher for confirmation) And... (thinking) ... and it didn't care when the other plants tried to stop it. It just... kept on being mean. Then... (voice gets softer) ... then it got hot and the rose started to wither... and it needed help from the cactus. (Looks up at the teacher, a little sad) That's all I remember about what the rose did. Was it being a bully?

That's a really good effort! You've remembered a lot about the rose's behaviour. You're right, it wasn't very kind. Now, let's dig a little deeper. You said the rose was "super beautiful." Why do you think the story makes such a point of saying that? What does the rose's beauty have to do with how it treated the cactus? Try to think about that for a moment.

(Thinking, tapping fingers on the desk) Hmmm... (Eyes widen slightly) Maybe... because the rose thought it was better than the cactus *because* it was beautiful? Like... it thought being pretty gave it permission to be mean? (Looks at the teacher, questioningly) Is that why? Did the rose think it was special just because of how it looked? (Frowns) That doesn't seem fair. (Pauses) Does being beautiful mean you get to be mean?

You've made some excellent points! You've really thought about why the rose acted that way. Now, to make sure we've got it all clear, could you quickly summarise everything we've said about the story so far? Try to put it all together in your own words, focusing on the rose, the cactus, and what we've learned about judging people based on how they look.

(Straightens up, confidently) Okay! The story is about a rose and a cactus in the desert. The rose was really beautiful and thought that meant it was better than the cactus. So it was mean and insulted the cactus all the time. But then, when it got hot, the cactus helped the birds and *then* helped the rose when it was withering. (Takes a breath) So... (looks down, then back up) ... the story teaches us that you shouldn't be mean to people just because you think you're prettier or better than them. And that you shouldn't judge people by how they look, because even if they don't look as pretty as you, they might be really kind and helpful. (Smiles proudly) Did I get it right?
Absolutely perfect! You've understood the story beautifully and explained it wonderfully. I'm so impressed with your thinking. Keep up the fantastic work, and I'll see you next time!

Absolutely perfect! You've understood the story beautifully and explained it wonderfully. I'm so impressed with your thinking. Keep up the fantastic work, and I'll see you next time!

record.strategy_description:
Okay, here's how we'll implement the "solo first then support" strategy with a student exhibiting low neuroticism:

First, I'll ask the student to retell the story *again*, focusing on the rose's actions. Then I will fill in the gaps, asking specific questions to get a deeper analysis. This will probably take two utterances.

record.summary: The student summarised the story, recalling the rose's insults to the cactus, the drought, and the cactus helping the birds and, eventually, the rose. Initially confident, the student became hesitant when recalling specific details. They showed curiosity about the rose's motivations and seemed saddened by the rose's actions, questioning if it was bullying.

The student retells the story, focusing on the rose's unkind behaviour and insults towards the cactus due to its obsession with its own beauty. Initially hesitant and looking away, the student gains confidence, using hand gestures while recounting the story. The student is also curious about the rose's motivations.

The student confidently recalled the story's setting and characters, initially focusing on the rose's unkindness and the cactus's helpfulness. Body language progressed from confident to hesitant, seeking confirmation, then brightening when discussing the cactus. They articulated the rose's insults, its beauty, and connected these to the story's moral.

dialogue: Hello! That's a fun story, isn't it? Can you tell me a little bit about what Molly did in the story? What was her job?
(Smiling politely) Yes, it was a fun story. Molly... (thinking) ...uh... her job was to milk the cows. And then... (looks away) ...she was going to sell the milk at the market.
That's a great start! You remembered her main job perfectly. What happened next after she decided to sell the milk at the market? You're doing so well remembering the details.

(Eyes widen slightly, showing interest) She... she saw a chicken! (Confidently) And she thought she could buy the chicken... so it could lay eggs! (Thinking) And then she could sell the eggs and have more money! ...uh... (hesitates)
That's exactly right! You're following the story really well. And what was she thinking about doing *after* she had the chicken and the eggs? You're doing a fantastic job!

(Thinking hard) She... (using complex words) ...she was... anticipating... uh... being able to buy lots of things! (Looks down, a bit shy) ...uh... and... (brightens up) make the other milkmaids jealous! (Asks a question, showing curiosity) Did she *really* think they would be jealous?

That's a very interesting question! It shows you're really thinking about the story. Before we decide if the other milkmaids *would* be jealous, let's finish telling what happened to Molly. You were doing such a good job! What happened *while* she was imagining all those wonderful things she could buy?
(Eyes widen, remembering) Oh! (Conscientiously) She was skipping... (lowers voice) and she spilled the milk! (Looks sad) ...uh... all of it. (Confidently) Then she had no milk to sell.

Excellent! You've remembered everything perfectly. Now, just to make sure we have the whole story clear in our minds, could you try to tell me the whole story of Molly, but using your own words? Try to include everything you've told me so far.

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize thoughts) Okay. (Confidently) Molly was a milkmaid, and she milked the cows. (Hesitates) ...uh... She was going to sell the milk at the market. (Brightens up) Then she saw a chicken and thought she could buy it and it would lay eggs! (Eyes widen with excitement) And then she could sell the eggs and have lots of money to buy things! (Looks down, shyly) ...uh... maybe to make the other milkmaids jealous. (Frowns slightly) But she was skipping and thinking about it so much... (voice gets softer) ...and she spilled all the milk! (Looks up, a little sad) So she had no milk and no money.

That's a fantastic retelling of the story! You remembered all the important details and explained them so well. You really understood what happened to Molly and why. Well done! I'm so glad we had this chat. Goodbye for now!

record.strategy_description:
Okay, here's how to implement motivational encouragement:

Focus on building the student's confidence by praising their initial response ("That's a great start! You remembered her main job perfectly."). Gently prompt them to elaborate with encouraging phrases like "What happened next?" or "You're doing great, keep going!". This should take 2 utterances.

record.summary: The student recapped Molly's job as a milkmaid and her plan to buy a chicken, sell its eggs, and buy more things. Initially, they were polite and hesitant, but grew more confident and enthusiastic when recalling the chicken and Molly's aspirations. Towards the end, they looked down shyly before brightening up and asking a question showing curiosity.

The student accurately described Molly's job and her plan to buy a chicken, sell eggs, and buy things. They correctly recalled Molly's imagined wealth and desire to make other milkmaids jealous. Hesitantly, they also mentioned she spilled the milk while skipping. The student smiled, widened their eyes with interest, and looked away while thinking.

The student has recounted Molly's job, her plan to buy a chicken and sell its eggs for profit, and her excitement about buying things and making others jealous. They also recalled the milk spilling due to her skipping. Initially polite and hesitant, the student gains confidence and enthusiasm throughout the conversation, becoming more engaged with the story.

dialogue: Hello! That's a lovely little story about the owl. Can you tell me, what do you think the owl spent his days doing?
Uh… (hesitates) He… he watched things? (looks away, thinking)
That's a great start! Watching things is definitely what he did. Can you tell me one thing that you think the owl *might* have watched near his oak tree? Even a small thing!
Hmm… (thinking, tapping fingers on desk) Maybe… squirrels? Running around? (looks at teacher, then back down at hands)
Yes, squirrels! That's a wonderful idea. I like how you're thinking about what lives around an oak tree. What do you think the owl thought about the squirrels running around?
(eyes widen a little) Um… Maybe… he wondered where they were going? (confidently) Because they were always… busy? (frowns a little, thinking hard) Is 'busy' a big word?

"Busy" is a *perfect* word! It fits just right. You're doing a fantastic job thinking about what the owl might have been wondering. Now, the story also mentions the owl *heard* things. What do you think he might have heard near his tree? Take your time, there's no rush.
(thinking, looks up at the ceiling) Uh… People talking? (pauses) The story said people told stories… maybe he heard… funny stories? (smiles shyly)

You've painted a wonderful picture of the owl's life! You've told me about him watching the squirrels, wondering where they were going because they were always busy, and you've imagined him listening to people telling funny stories. That's a lot! Could you put all those ideas together and tell me in your own words what the owl did every day?

(takes a deep breath, fidgets with pencil) Okay… (pauses) He… he watched squirrels running around… and wondered why they were so busy. (looks at teacher) And he listened to people… telling stories. (confidently) That’s what he did every day! Did he learn from the stories?

That's a brilliant summary! You've really understood what the owl did each day. And that's a *great* question! Did he learn from the stories? Think about that, and maybe we can talk about it next time. You did so well today! Goodbye for now!

record.summary: The student, after some hesitation and looking away, correctly stated the owl spent his days watching things. They suggested the owl watched squirrels and wondered about their busyness. They were tapping fingers and looking down, indicating thoughtfulness, before confidently suggesting "busy," then questioning if it was too big a word.

The student understands the owl watched things, like squirrels, and wondered why they were busy. They also grasped that the owl heard people telling stories, possibly funny ones. The student initially hesitated and looked away, but gained confidence, using hand gestures and smiling shyly as they progressed.

The student was initially hesitant, looking away, but gained confidence, making eye contact and speaking more assuredly.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the farmer and the golden goose. It's a pretty interesting one, isn't it? What's the first thing that comes to your mind when you think about the farmer?
(Thinking, tapping foot slightly) Uh… the farmer… (looks away, then back at the teacher, confidently) he wasn't very… um… judicious? He wanted… more.
That's a great word, "judicious"! Can you tell me a bit more about what you mean by that? What wasn't very judicious about what he did?

(Straightens up, confident) Well, he already had a golden egg every day! That's a lot! (Slight pause) But he wanted all the golden eggs… all at once. He didn’t think about… um… (searching for the word) sustainability? (Looks at the teacher, questioningly) Is that right?

That's a very insightful way to put it! "Sustainability" is a big word and it fits here. He wasn't thinking about the future, was he? Tell me, what do you think made him want *all* the golden eggs at once? What was he hoping to achieve?

(Nods, understanding) He wanted to be… (pauses, thinking) … Affluent! (Looks at the teacher, proud of the word choice). He wanted to be rich… really fast. He didn't want to wait for the goose to lay one egg each day. He was… (hesitates) … impatient. (Looks down at hands)

That's a perfect word, "impatient." So, he was impatient and wanted to be affluent quickly. Can you tell me a bit more about *why* being impatient and wanting to be rich quickly led him to make such a bad decision? What was he *not* thinking about?

(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) He wasn't thinking about… the goose! (Looks up, concerned) The goose was… you know… the *source* of the eggs. (Pauses) And he wasn't thinking about… uh… consequences? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) If he killed the goose… no more eggs! (Shakes head slightly)

You've explained that so well! You've covered the farmer's impatience, his desire to be rich quickly, and how he didn't think about the goose or the consequences of his actions. Now, in your own words, can you give me a short summary of everything we've talked about regarding why the farmer made such a foolish choice?

(Takes a deep breath, organizes thoughts) Okay… (confidently) The farmer was… too eager to be wealthy. He wasn't judicious. He wanted to be affluent immediately, but he should have been more patient and thought about the long-term... (Pauses, choosing words carefully) …the sustained yield… of the golden eggs. He didn't think about the goose, the origin of his wealth, and what would happen if he… eliminated… it. So, he made a bad choice. (Looks at the teacher, awaiting approval)

That's a brilliant summary! You've really understood the story and the farmer's mistake. Well done! I'm so impressed with how well you've explained everything today. Goodbye, and I'll see you next time.

Initially, the student seemed hesitant but gained confidence as the discussion progressed, using sophisticated vocabulary while occasionally looking to the teacher for affirmation and ending by looking down at their hands.

The student has identified the farmer as unjudicious, driven by impatience to become affluent quickly, neglecting the goose's role as the sustainable source of the golden eggs and failing to consider the consequences. Initially hesitant (foot tapping), the student becomes more confident (straightening up) but occasionally seeks confirmation from the teacher (questioning looks).

dialogue: Hello! That's a clever story about the farmer and his neighbour. Can you tell me in your own words what the problem was between them?
(Looks away, thinking) Uh… The farmer… he bought the well… (stuttering) but… the neighbour… wouldn't let him use the water? (Confidently) Because he said he only sold the well, not the water inside!
That's right! You've got the main idea. What do you think the farmer felt about that?

(Thinking, using complex words) Hmmm... (Looks down) I think... he felt... (confidently) betrayed! Because he needed the water for his farm, and it's kind of... implied... that when you buy a well, you get the water too! (Looking up, curiously) Teacher, why do people try to trick other people?

That's a really insightful question! People try to trick others for lots of reasons, sometimes because they think it will benefit them in some way. But you're right, it's not a very nice thing to do. Now, going back to the story, you used a great word – "betrayed." How do you think the *emperor* felt about the neighbour's trick?

(Thinking, looks very organized) Well... the emperor is supposed to be fair, right? (Confidently) So, he probably thought the neighbor was being... (hesitates, searching for the right word) ...unjust! Yes, unjust! (Looks at the teacher, interested) The emperor wanted everyone to be treated fairly.
Excellent! "Unjust" is exactly the right word. You're really understanding this story. Now, what do you think the *courtier* was trying to achieve by asking the neighbour about the water?

(Eyes widen, thinks beyond the given information) Hmmm... (confident) The courtier was trying to...trick the tricky neighbour! (Explains logically) He wanted the neighbour to get caught in his own trick. (Asks question to teacher) Like, if the neighbour said he *didn't* sell the water, then the courtier knew the neighbour was just being mean and not fair! Right?

You've followed the story and the characters' actions so well! You've explained how the farmer, emperor, neighbour, and courtier felt and what they were trying to do. Could you put all those pieces together and give me a short summary of everything we've talked about so far about the story?

(Thinks carefully, organizing thoughts) Okay... (confidently) The farmer bought a well, but the neighbor wouldn't let him use the water. The farmer felt betrayed, so he went to the emperor. The emperor thought the neighbor was being unjust. The courtier tricked the tricky neighbor so he would get caught! (Smiles politely) Is that a good summary, Teacher?
That's a fantastic summary! You've really understood the story and all the clever things the characters did. Well done! I'm so glad you enjoyed it. Goodbye for now, and keep up the great work!

dialogue: Hello! That's a lovely story about the elephant. Can you tell me in your own words what the elephant was trying to do at the beginning of the story?
(Looks down, thinking) Uh… the elephant… (hesitates) …wanted… friends? (Looks up quickly, then down again) He was, like, looking for… playmates? Maybe companions? (Confidently) To not be lonely!

Yes, exactly! He wanted friends. You got that! And "not to be lonely!" That's a great way to put it! You're doing a super job understanding the story. What happened when the elephant tried to make friends with the other animals? Don't worry if you can't remember every little detail, just tell me what you can.

(Thinking hard, tapping fingers on the table) Hmmm… (pauses) The… (stuttering) …the monkey… said no? (Looks up, a little unsure) Because… the elephant couldn’t climb? And the rabbit… (confidently) The rabbit said he was too big for the burrow! (Tilts head, furrowing brow) And the frog… something about jumping? (Looks at teacher expectantly) They all said no… (sadly) to being his friend.

That's fantastic! You remembered so much! The monkey, the rabbit, and the frog – you got them all right! And you explained perfectly *why* they each said no. You're doing a brilliant job! So, the elephant asked lots of animals to be friends, and they all said no. How do you think that made the elephant feel? It's okay to guess!

(Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor) Uh… (pauses, thinking) Sad? (Looks up, eyes widening slightly) Maybe… rejected? (Confidently) Because he was big! (Frowns slightly) Like, they didn’t *want* him because he was… elephant-sized? (Looks at teacher for confirmation)

Yes, "sad" and "rejected" are perfect words to describe how the elephant probably felt! You're really understanding how the elephant was feeling in the story. And you're right, it seemed like they didn't want him because he was so big.

Now, the story doesn't end there! After all those rejections, something else happened in the forest. Can you remember what happened the next day? Even a little bit helps!

(Thinking, biting lip slightly) …Um… (eyes widen) …running! (Confidently) All the animals were running! (Looks up, excited) Because… because the tiger was… attacking? (Tilts head, confused) I think? (Looks at teacher for help)

That's right! All the animals were running because the tiger was attacking! You got it! You're doing so well remembering the story.

Before we move on, can you quickly tell me everything you remember about the story so far? Just a quick recap in your own words! It will help us put all the pieces together!

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize thoughts. Fidgets with hands.) Okay… (Confidently) The elephant wanted friends. (Hesitates) But the monkey couldn't… um… swing with him? And the rabbit’s burrow was too small. (Looks away, remembering) The frog… jumping? Then… (Excitedly) The tiger! The animals were running! (Looks at the teacher, proud) Did I do good?

You did amazing! You remembered all the important parts – the elephant's loneliness, the reasons for rejection, and the tiger attacking. You put all the pieces together beautifully! I'm so proud of how well you understood the story and its message about friendship. Have a wonderful day!

(Looks down, scuffing shoe on the floor) Uh… (pauses, thinking) Sad? (Looks up, eyes widening slightly) Maybe… rejected? (Confidently) Because he was big! (Frowns slightly) Like, they didn’t *want* him because he was… elephant-sized? (Looks at teacher for confirmation)

Yes, "sad" and "rejected" are perfect words to describe how the elephant probably felt! You're really understanding how the elephant was feeling in the story. And you're right, it seemed like they didn't want him because he was so big.

Now, the story doesn't end there! After all those rejections, something else happened in the forest. Can you remember what happened the next day? Even a little bit helps!

(Thinking, biting lip slightly) …Um… (eyes widen) …running! (Confidently) All the animals were running! (Looks up, excited) Because… because the tiger was… attacking? (Tilts head, confused) I think? (Looks at teacher for help)

That's right! All the animals were running because the tiger was attacking! You got it! You're doing so well remembering the story.

Before we move on, can you quickly tell me everything you remember about the story so far? Just a quick recap in your own words! It will help us put all the pieces together!

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize thoughts. Fidgets with hands.) Okay… (Confidently) The elephant wanted friends. (Hesitates) But the monkey couldn't… um… swing with him? And the rabbit’s burrow was too small. (Looks away, remembering) The frog… jumping? Then… (Excitedly) The tiger! The animals were running! (Looks at the teacher, proud) Did I do good?

You did amazing! You remembered all the important parts – the elephant's loneliness, the reasons for rejection, and the tiger attacking. You put all the pieces together beautifully! I'm so proud of how well you understood the story and its message about friendship. Have a wonderful day!

record.strategy_description:
Okay, here's how to implement motivational encouragement:

Acknowledge the student's correct answers and efforts ("Yes, exactly! He wanted friends, you got that!"). Build confidence with positive reinforcement ("'Not to be lonely!' That's a great way to put it!"). This should take 1-2 utterances.

The student recalls the elephant's initial loneliness and attempts to make friends, including the monkey, rabbit, and frog's rejections based on the elephant's size and abilities. The student seemed unsure while recalling, often looking down and hesitating, but showed increased confidence when remembering details.

The student displayed initial hesitation, gaining confidence and excitement as they recounted the story, often looking to the teacher for reassurance.

dialogue: Okay, let's explore this story together! It sounds like a good one. What part of the story stood out to you the most when you first heard it?

(Confidently) Uh… the tea!

(Looks at the teacher, a bit hesitant, then clarifies using a more complex word) Because… the tea *transformed* the water!

That's a great observation about the tea! It's really powerful how it changed the water itself. Can you think of a time, maybe at school or at home, where you saw someone, or maybe even *you*, change a situation or the mood of a place, kind of like the tea did with the water?

(Thinking, eyes widening a little) Hmmm… (Stuttering) Uh… like, when… when Maya… (More confidently) When Maya was sad because she didn’t get to play the fairy in the play? And then I… (Hesitates) …I gave her my… (Confidently) …my sparkly headband and she felt better?

(Looks at the teacher expectantly)

That's a wonderful example! Maya was sad, and your sparkly headband helped change her mood. So, you helped transform a sad situation into a happier one, just like the tea transformed the water.

Now, thinking about that, was it *just* the headband itself that made Maya feel better, or was there something else involved? What do you think *you* did that helped?

(Thinking, uses fingers to count something silently) …Uh… (Looks down, then back up) Maybe… (Complex word coming!) …*empathy*?

(Looks at the teacher, unsure if that was the right word)

Empathy is a *fantastic* word! You're right, it wasn't *just* the headband, was it? Think about it – you saw Maya was sad, and you *chose* to do something to help. How do you think knowing that *you* understood her feelings made Maya feel?

(Nods slowly, thinking hard) …Uh… Happy? (Hesitates) …Because… (Complex thought!) …because I… (Confidently) …*acknowledged* her sadness!

(Looks at the teacher, proud of figuring it out)

You've made so many great connections! You understood the story, you understood empathy, you even helped Maya! Now, could you try and put it all together? In your own words, can you tell me what we've learned about the egg, the potato, the tea, and how *you* helped Maya? Just a quick summary to wrap things up!

(Thinking, bites lip slightly, then answers confidently) Okay! The egg… (Points a finger up) …it was soft and then hard. The potato… (Points another finger up) …was hard and then soft. And the tea… (Points a third finger up)… the tea changed the water! (Pauses) And… and… (Thinks hard) …adversity is like the hot water! (Looks at the teacher for confirmation) And… (Confident again) …I helped Maya by being… *empathetic*… and… (Slight hesitation)… giving her my headband! So… (Big smile, completely confident now) …adversity can change things, but we can change them back… (Complex word!) …or even… *transform* them!

Absolutely brilliant! You've truly understood everything, and explained it so well. You should be very proud of yourself! Now, run along and have a wonderful day, and keep using that fantastic empathy to help others! Goodbye!

dialogue: Hello! That's a lovely story. Can you tell me in your own words what the story is about? Take your time and think about it carefully.

Uh... (looks down at my shoes) It's... uh... about two brothers. (fidgets with my hands) The older one... he wasn't very nice. (thinking) He found a tree that gave him... golden apples... but he wanted more! (eyes widen slightly) And then... needles! So many needles! (looks back up at the teacher) And then... the younger brother helped him. And... the tree gave them more apples. (smiles shyly)

That's a fantastic start! You've remembered so many important details. I especially liked how you described the needles – "So many needles!" – that really paints a picture. Now, can you tell me a little bit more about why the older brother wasn't very nice? What did he do that wasn't kind? Don't worry if you don't remember every single detail, just tell me what you can.

(Thinking hard, furrowing my brow) He... he was mean to his brother. (pauses) The story said... (looks at the teacher expectantly) ...he was *always* mean. And... (uses my fingers to count) he wanted *more* apples, even though the tree gave him some already. Was that... greedy? (looks up at the teacher with a questioning look, hoping for confirmation)

Yes, that's exactly right! Wanting more even after being given something is often called being greedy. You've picked up on a very important part of the story. You're doing a wonderful job remembering everything.

Now, can you tell me *how* he was mean to his younger brother? The story says he was "always mean." What do you think that might have looked like? Even a guess is perfect!

(Stares at my hands again, thinking. Then, a small lightbulb seems to go off) Maybe... maybe he didn't share his... toys? (Hesitates) Or... or maybe he took the best seat at the table? (Looks up, a little more confident) And maybe... maybe he didn't say "thank you" when his brother helped him with something? (Frowns slightly, trying to remember more) I... I think those are things that aren't nice, right?

Those are excellent examples! Not sharing, taking the best seat, and not saying "thank you" are definitely not kind things to do. You're really understanding what it means to be mean.

You're doing such a great job piecing everything together. Now, thinking about the end of the story, what happened *after* the older brother got hurt? What did the younger brother do then? Take your time, there's no rush. Even just a little bit of what you remember is great!

(Eyes widen as I remember) Oh! (Sits up a little straighter) He... he helped him! (Nods emphatically) He took out all the needles! (Grimaces slightly, imagining the needles) That must have hurt! (Pauses) And then... and *then* the older brother said sorry! (Looks at the teacher, thoughtfully) Was that... was that why the tree gave them more apples? Because he said sorry? (Tilts head slightly, curious)

That's a very insightful question! You're absolutely right to connect the apology to the tree giving more apples. You've remembered so many important details, from the older brother's initial greed to the younger brother's kindness and the apology.

Before we explore the 'why' a bit more, could you try to summarise for me everything you've told me about the story so far? Just in your own words, tell me the story again, focusing on the important bits we've talked about.

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize my thoughts. Focuses intently) Okay... (Starts a little hesitantly, then gains confidence) There were two brothers, and the older one was always mean. He found a magic tree that gave him golden apples, but he was greedy and wanted more. So the tree gave him needles instead! The younger brother helped him take out the needles, and then the older brother said he was sorry for being mean. And then... (Smiles brightly, remembering the happy ending) ...the tree gave them even *more* golden apples! (Looks at the teacher, pleased with myself)

That's a fantastic summary! You remembered everything perfectly and explained it so well. You really understood the story and why things happened the way they did. Well done! It was wonderful working with you today. Have a great rest of your day!

dialogue: Hello! That's a lovely story. Can you tell me, what was the fox looking for in the story?
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Food?
Yes, food! Great job! You remembered that. Now, can you tell me *where* did the fox find the yummy-looking grapes? Take your time; it's okay if you need a moment to think.
(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Um... a wall? A farmer's wall? (Looks up at the teacher hopefully)
Yes, a farmer's wall! You're doing wonderfully! Now, can you describe the grapes? What did they look like? Try your best!
(Hesitates) Purple... and... big? Juicy? (Looks away, nervously) ...Uh...

Purple, big, and juicy! That's a fantastic description! You're doing so well! Now, what did the fox do when he saw these delicious grapes? Did he just stand there and look at them? What do you think he wanted to do? Don't worry if you're not sure; just take a guess!
(Shakes head slightly) No... He... jumped? (Looks down at my shoes) He wanted to eat them, I think... (voice is barely a whisper)

That's right! He jumped because he wanted to eat them. Excellent! You've remembered so much. Now, just to be absolutely sure we understand everything, could you quickly tell me everything you've told me about the story so far? Just a quick summary in your own words! You can do it!

(My eyes widen, looking overwhelmed) Oh... um... (Stuttering) The fox... uh... wanted food. And he saw... purple... juicy grapes... on a farmer's wall. And he... jumped for them. (Looks at the teacher with a pleading expression) Is that... okay?

That's perfect! Absolutely perfect! You got all the important parts. You explained it so well, even though I know it can be a little nerve-wracking to tell a story. I'm so proud of how hard you tried and how much you remembered. Well done! Have a wonderful day!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the rose and the cactus. What did you think about it after reading it? Did anything stand out to you?
(Looks down, fiddling with my hands) Uh… (Stuttering) It… it was… about a rose and a cactus. (Hesitates)

That's right! It *is* about a rose and a cactus – great start! You noticed the most important characters.

Now, don't worry about getting anything wrong. Just tell me, can you tell me one thing the rose did in the story? Even a small detail is perfect.
(Thinking hard, brows furrowed) …The rose… (Looks away, nervously) …it… it was… mean. (Quietly) to the cactus.

That's excellent! You're exactly right. The rose *was* mean to the cactus. That's a really important detail. You're doing great!

Now, can you remember *why* the rose was mean? What did the rose think about itself? Take your time, no pressure at all.
(Bites lip, hesitates) (Whispers) Pretty… (Looks down again) The rose… thought it was pretty. And… and the cactus… wasn't.

That's absolutely right! The rose thought it was pretty, and you remembered that the cactus wasn't treated well because of it. That's fantastic work! You're really understanding the story.

Now, let's think about what happened *after* the rose was mean. What happened during the hot summer? Just a little hint is all we need!
(Anxious, fidgeting with fingers) Uh… (Stutters) Hot… (Whispers) no water…

Yes, that's right! It was very hot, and there was no water. You've remembered all the important parts so far.

Now, before we move on, could you quickly tell me everything you've remembered about the story so far, just in your own words? It'll help us make sure we understand it all before we continue.

(Looks down, nervously) (Takes a deep breath) Okay… (Quietly) There was a rose and a cactus… in the desert. The rose was… mean… to the cactus… because it thought it was… pretty. And then… it was hot… and there was no water. (Looks up briefly, then down again)
That's a perfect summary! You remembered everything so well, even though you were a little nervous. You should be really proud of yourself! Keep up the fantastic work, and have a wonderful day!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of Molly the milkmaid. What did Molly do for work? Can you tell me in your own words?
(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting) Uh... Molly... milked the cows. (Hesitates) And... and she was going to... sell the milk. At the... market. (Looks up quickly, then back down)

That's right! You remembered perfectly. Molly milked the cows and was going to sell the milk at the market. That's a great start!

Now, what happened while Molly was walking to the market? Can you remember what she started to think about? It's okay if you don't remember everything, just tell me what you can.
(Thinking hard, furrowing brow) ...She... (Stuttering) S-she... thought about... money. (Looks at the teacher briefly, then down again) How... how she would... spend it. (Whispers) on things.

That's absolutely right! You're doing so well. Molly did start thinking about the money and how she would spend it.

Now, can you remember *one* thing she thought she might buy with the money? Don't worry if you can't remember everything, just one thing is perfect. Take your time and think about it. Maybe thinking about the animals in the story will help.
(Eyes widen slightly, then quickly dart away) A... a chicken. (Whispers) She wanted a chicken. (Looks at the floor)

That's fantastic! You remembered she wanted a chicken. That's a really important part of the story!

dialogue: Hello there! That's a lovely little story, isn't it? Can you tell me in your own words what the owl in the story did every day?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh… um… (stuttering) The owl… saw things… near the tree.
That's a start! You noticed the owl saw things. Great! Can you tell me *one* specific thing the owl might have seen near the tree?
(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) …People… (looks away) talking.

That's right! People talking! Excellent! You're doing so well. Now, the story also mentions the owl *heard* things. Can you guess what kind of things the owl might have heard the people talking about? Maybe they were telling...?
(Hesitates, looks at the teacher briefly, then back down at my hands) Stories?

Yes! Stories! You got it! That's fantastic. See, you remembered! Now, think about this: if the owl is seeing things and hearing stories every day, what do you think might happen to the owl over time? Do you think he'd stay the same, or might he change in some way?
(Eyes widen a little, thinking. Furrows brow.) Change…? (Quietly)

That's a good start. He changes... How does he change? Think about what the story says happens to him because he sees and hears so much. Don't worry, take your time. Can you tell me everything you've said about the owl so far? Just tell me the story in your own words, as best as you can remember.
(Swallows hard, looks at the floor) Okay... (Takes a deep breath) The owl... sees people... (Stuttering) and hears... stories... (Looks up quickly, then down again) …and he... changes...?

That's perfect! You've got all the important pieces. He sees, he hears, and he changes. And the story tells us *how* he changes, doesn't it? He becomes wiser. Now you know the whole story, and that makes me so happy! You did a wonderful job today. Remember, it's okay to take your time and think things through. Well done, and I'll see you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the farmer and the golden goose. It's quite a sad story, isn't it? What did you think about it when you first heard it?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... (pauses) ... it was sad. (Quietly) The goose... didn't do anything wrong.
You're right, it is sad. Can you tell me one thing the goose did in the story?
(Thinking hard, bites lip) It... (stuttering) it laid... a golden egg? (Looks up briefly, then back down)
That's right, the goose laid golden eggs. Did the goose do anything *bad*?
(Shakes head slowly) N-no. (Looks at the teacher, then quickly away. Voice barely a whisper) It... just laid eggs.
You're doing so well. You're exactly right, the goose just laid eggs, and those eggs were special. Did the farmer *ask* the goose to lay the golden eggs, or did the goose just do it on its own?
(Thinking, brows furrowed) ...On its own? (Looks at teacher with a questioning glance) He... he didn't *ask*.

You've picked up on some really important parts of the story. You've noticed the goose laid the eggs all by itself and it wasn't doing anything wrong. You also know the farmer didn't ask the goose for them. Could you put all those things together for me in a few sentences? Tell me everything you remember about the story up to this point.

(Hesitates, looking at the floor) Uh... (Shuffles feet) The farmer... had a goose. (Pauses, thinking) And... the goose gave him golden eggs. All by itself. (Looks up, nervous) Without... without asking. (Looks down again)
That's a fantastic summary! You've remembered all the important details. You've worked really hard to understand the story and I'm proud of you. Well done, and have a good day!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the farmer and the well. Can you tell me, in your own words, what the story is about? Don't worry about getting it perfect, just tell me what you remember.

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... (hesitates) The farmer... he wanted water... and he bought a well... from his neighbor. (Looks up briefly, then back down) But the neighbor... he didn't... uh... let him use the water. (Stuttering slightly) The farmer... went to the emperor... for help.

That's a great start! You remembered the most important parts. It's okay if you don't remember every single detail right away.

Now, let's think about why the neighbour wouldn't let the farmer use the water. What reason did the neighbour give for not letting him take any water?

(Thinking hard, biting my lip)

He... (long pause) ...he said... (looks away) ...he sold the well... but not... the water? (Sounds like a question)

Yes, that's exactly right! You remembered that tricky part! See, you're doing great!

Now, the emperor's courtier had a clever idea. What did the courtier suggest the neighbour should do about the water he claimed he still owned?

(Eyes wide, a little anxious)

Uh... (fumbling with my fingers) ...the courtier... said... (whispers) ...pay rent? Or... (hesitates again) ...take the water away? (Looks up at the teacher, hoping for confirmation)

Yes, you're absolutely right! You remembered the two choices the courtier gave him: pay rent or take the water away. Fantastic! You're doing such a good job remembering the story, even the tricky parts!

Now, think about this: could the neighbour *really* take all the water away? Where would he put it? What do you think happened when the neighbour realised how silly his trick was?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed)

...Uh... (Looks down at my shoes) He couldn't... take it all away. (Shakes head slightly) It was... in the well. And... and he didn't have anywhere to put it... (Voice gets quieter) He was... tricked? (Looks up, a little uncertain)

That's excellent! You've got it! He realised he couldn't possibly take the water away.

Now, you've remembered so many important parts of the story. Could you try to tell me everything we've talked about, from the farmer buying the well to the neighbour realising his trick wouldn't work? Just put it all together in your own words, okay? Take your time.

(Takes a deep breath, looks down again, and speaks slowly)

The farmer... he bought a well... from his neighbor. But... the neighbor said... he didn't buy the water. Only the well. So he wouldn't... let the farmer use it. The farmer... went to the emperor. The courtier... he said the neighbor had to... pay rent for the water... or take it away. But... (Looks up briefly, then back down) the neighbor couldn't take it away! Because... it's a lot of water... and he had nowhere to put it. So... (quietly) ...he was sorry.

That's a perfect retelling of the story! You remembered all the important parts so clearly, and you explained why the neighbor's trick didn't work. I'm so proud of you! Well done today; I'll see you next time!

dialogue: Hello there! That's a lovely story about the elephant. Can you tell me, what was the elephant looking for at the beginning of the story?
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Friends? The elephant... uh... wanted friends. (Hesitates)

That's right! The elephant wanted friends. That's a great start! (Smile warmly). It's okay to feel a little unsure, we'll take it one small step at a time.

Now, can you remember *why* the monkey didn't want to be friends with the elephant? Just a little reminder, it had something to do with what monkeys like to do best.
(Thinking, brows furrowed) Um... because... (Stuttering) ...it couldn't... swing? (Looks at the teacher hesitantly) The monkey... likes swinging... and the elephant... can't.

That's absolutely right! The monkey likes swinging, and the elephant can't. You're doing so well! (Give a reassuring nod).

Now, let's think about the rabbit. Do you remember what rabbits like to do? It's something small and cozy... Can you remember why the elephant couldn't do it? Just try your best, and it's perfectly fine if you need a moment to think. We'll get there together!
(Looks away, biting lip) Rabbits... go in... burrows? (Looks back at the teacher with a worried expression). The elephant... is too big? (Whispers) Is that right?

Yes, that's exactly right! Rabbits go in burrows, and the elephant is too big to fit. You remembered that perfectly! (Smile encouragingly)

See? You *can* do this! Now, just one more animal turned the elephant down. Can you remember which one it was? Don't worry if you don't get it right away, just take a guess. Even guessing shows you're trying, and that's what matters!
(Thinking hard, tapping fingers on the table) Um... (Long pause) ...frog? (Looks up, hopeful) The frog said no?

Yes, you're spot on! The frog *did* say no. You're remembering all the details so well, even the tricky ones! You should feel really proud of yourself.

Now, to make sure we have all the pieces together, could you try to tell me everything we've talked about so far, in your own words? Start with the elephant wanting friends, and go through all the animals who said no, and why. Take your time, and don't worry if you miss something – we can always go back and fill it in!

(Takes a deep breath, looking down at hands) Okay... The elephant... wanted friends. But the monkey... said no. Because... the elephant couldn't swing. (Pauses, looking up briefly). And the rabbit... said no too. Because... elephant was too big for the burrow. And... the frog... also said no. (Looks down again, voice getting quieter) I... I don't remember why the frog said no. (Frowns, starting to get anxious).

That's a fantastic summary so far! You remembered so many details perfectly, and it's okay that you don't remember *every single* thing about the frog right now. What’s important is you tried your best! The frog didn’t think the elephant could jump. But you know what? You've worked so hard today, and I'm really impressed with how much you've remembered. You're doing great! Let's stop here for today, and you can give yourself a big pat on the back for all your effort! We can pick up again next time. Have a wonderful day!
