dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the farmer and the golden goose. It's a bit sad, isn't it? What do you think was the farmer's biggest mistake?

(Fidgets with my pencil, looking down at the desk) Uh... (pauses) ... Um... He... (Stuttering) He wanted... too much? (Looks up at the teacher nervously, then back down at the desk). It was... bad... to want so much. (Thinking) He... he should have been happy.

Yes, wanting too much was definitely part of it! That's a great start. Can you remember one *thing* he *did* because he wanted too much? Don't worry if you're not sure, just give it your best guess. You're doing great so far!

(Looks up, eyes wide, then back down at the desk, picking at a loose thread on my sleeve). He... (long pause) ...Cut...? (voice barely a whisper) ... the goose? (Frowns, like the thought is unpleasant). He... (another pause) ... I don't... I don't like that part. (Hugs myself a little). He shouldn't have done that. Was that... was that a bad thing to do?

Yes, you're absolutely right. Cutting the goose was a very bad thing to do. It's okay if that part is upsetting; it *is* upsetting! You're showing you understand the story very well by recognizing that.

Now, thinking about *why* he cut the goose... you said he wanted too much. What did he *think* he would find inside the goose? Remember, before he cut it, what was he hoping for? Take your time; it's perfectly fine to think about it.

(Chews on my lip, thinking hard. Looks up at the ceiling, then back at the teacher, a glimmer of understanding in my eyes). More...? (Frowns, trying to find the words). He thought... thought there were lots...lots of golden eggs... inside? (Voice gets a little louder, like I'm getting excited). Like... a treasure chest! But... but there wasn't, right? Just... just yucky stuff. (Wrinkles my nose in disgust).

That's *exactly* right! He thought there was a treasure chest of golden eggs inside. You're doing so well figuring this out!

And you're also right that there wasn't a treasure chest, just... yucky stuff.

Now, here's the big question: Because he thought that, and because he cut the goose... what happened *afterwards*? What did he lose because he made that bad choice? Take a deep breath, you can do it! What was the *result* of cutting open the goose?

(Takes a deep breath, like the teacher said. My face scrunches up as I try to remember). Um... (Quietly) ... No more... golden eggs? (Looks at the teacher, anxiously awaiting confirmation). He... he didn't get any more. And... (eyes start to water a little) ... and they became... poor? (Whispers the last word, looking very upset). Is that right? He was silly, wasn't he? (Sniffles). He lost everything.

Yes, that's completely right. No more golden eggs, and they became poor. He *did* lose everything because of his silly, greedy choice. You've understood the story so well, even though it's a sad one.

Now, to make sure we've got it all clear, can you tell me the whole story again, but in your own words? Just tell me what happened from beginning to end, focusing on why the farmer did what he did and what happened because of it. Take your time, and don't worry if you miss a little detail; just try to remember the most important parts. You can do it!

(Wipes my eyes with the back of my hand). Okay... (Takes another deep breath).

There was a farmer... and he had a goose... and it gave him a golden egg... every day. (Pauses, thinking). He was... happy... but then... (Frowns) ... he wanted more. He got... greedy. (Says the word "greedy" like it's a bad taste in my mouth).

He thought... if he cut the goose open... he'd find lots and lots of golden eggs... like a big pile! (Looks at the teacher, nervously). But... there weren't any. (Voice gets quiet again). Just... just yucky stuff.

And then... (Looks down at my hands, twisting them in my lap) ... he didn't have any more golden eggs... and he became poor. He was silly... and he lost everything... because he wanted too much. (Sniffles again). That's the story. (Looks up at the teacher, hopefully). Was that okay?

That was perfect! You told the story beautifully, and you really understood why the farmer made the wrong choice and what happened because of it. You should be very proud of yourself. I think you've learned a lot from this story. Well done! I have to go now but I will see you next time. Goodbye!

He thought... if he cut the goose open... he'd find lots and lots of golden eggs... like a big pile! (Looks at the teacher, nervously). But... there weren't any. (Voice gets quiet again). Just... just yucky stuff.

And then... (Looks down at my hands, twisting them in my lap) ... he didn't have any more golden eggs... and he became poor. He was silly... and he lost everything... because he wanted too much. (Sniffles again). That's the story. (Looks up at the teacher, hopefully). Was that okay?

That was perfect! You told the story beautifully, and you really understood why the farmer made the wrong choice and what happened because of it. You should be very proud of yourself. I think you've learned a lot from this story. Well done! I have to go now but I will see you next time. Goodbye!

Can you tell me one thing he did that showed he wanted too much?" (Utterance 1) followed by positive reinforcement like "Great thinking!". This could take 2-3 utterances.

They are visibly uncomfortable with that part of the story, fidgeting, looking down, and speaking softly. They correctly identified the farmer's mistaken belief that the goose held a treasure trove of eggs.

The student, fidgeting and looking down, initially identified the farmer's greed as his mistake and then reluctantly recalled him cutting the goose. Upset by this act, the student understood the farmer hoped to find a treasure of eggs inside. Finally, the student, looking upset, recalled the consequence: no more eggs and the farmer's poverty.

The student, displaying nervous body language like fidgeting and avoiding eye contact, has grasped that the farmer's greed led him to cut open the goose, expecting a treasure of golden eggs. Consequently, the farmer lost his source of income and became poor. The student showed distaste and sadness while narrating the events.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about this story! It's a bit tricky, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most? Maybe something that made you feel a certain way?

(Fidgets with my hands, looks at the floor) Uh… (long pause)… the… the neighbor… (nervously glances up at the teacher)

(Another long pause, chewing on my lip) The neighbor… was… um… mean? (My voice wavers) He… he sold the well, but didn't want the farmer to get water? That… that doesn't make sense. (Wrinkles my nose in confusion) Why would he do that?

That's a really good observation! You're right, it doesn't make much sense at first, does it? You noticed that the neighbor was being mean – that shows you're thinking about how his actions affected the farmer. And you're absolutely right to be confused, because it *is* confusing!

Let's think about *why* the neighbor might have done that. Even if it seems mean, maybe he thought he was being clever? What do you think the neighbor was trying to *get* by doing that? Don't worry if you're not sure, just take a guess!

(Eyes widen, thinking hard) Hmm… (scratches my head). Maybe… maybe he wanted more money? (Looks up, hesitantly) Did he… did he want the farmer to pay him even MORE after he already bought the well? Like… like a trick? (Frowns, twisting my fingers together) It's… it's not fair, is it? (Voice trembling slightly)

That's excellent! You're spot on! It *was* a trick! You're very clever for figuring that out. He *did* want more money, even after selling the well. You're right, it's definitely not fair.

Now, you've figured out *what* the neighbor did and *why* he did it. Let's think about what happened *next*. The farmer was upset, right? What did he do because the neighbor was being unfair?

(Sniffles, wiping my nose with my sleeve) He… he went to… to the… (struggles to remember) the… um… the big… (panicked look) I… I forgot the word! (Starts to get teary-eyed) The… the important person! (Forces the words out) The emperor! (Looks down at my shoes, ashamed). I… I couldn't remember.

It's okay, it's okay! You remembered in the end, and that's what matters. See? You knew it all along! You're doing wonderfully.

Now, before we go any further, let's just take a deep breath. (Pause) Okay. You've explained so much about the story already. Can you tell me, in your own words, everything that's happened so far from the beginning? Just tell me the story like you're telling it to a friend.

(Takes a shaky breath, trying to calm down). Okay… okay. (Looks around the room, then focuses on the teacher). There was a farmer… and he needed water for his farm… so he bought a well from his neighbor. But… (voice cracks) … the neighbor was being mean… (frowns) … and wouldn't let him use the water… even though he bought the well! So… (hesitates) … the farmer got sad and went to the… the Emperor! (Speaks the word "Emperor" a little louder, feeling more confident). Because… because it wasn't fair! (Looks at the teacher, seeking approval). Did… did I get it right so far?

You got it exactly right! That was a perfect summary, and you told it so well. You should be really proud of yourself. Now, I have to go help some other students, but you keep thinking about what happened next in the story, okay? You're doing a fantastic job! Bye for now!

They deduced the neighbor's motive was to trick the farmer for more money, recognizing the unfairness. The student, while fidgeting and avoiding eye contact, explained the story's beginning: a farmer buys a well, but the neighbor refuses him water. dialogue: Hi there! That's a lovely story. Shall we try and understand it better together? Perhaps we can start by talking about how the elephant was feeling at the beginning? What do you think?
(Looks down, fiddling with my shoelaces) Uh... okay. The elephant... (stutters) was... sad? Because nobody... nobody wanted to be its friend. (Looks up quickly, then back down) It was lonely.

That's absolutely right! The elephant was feeling sad and lonely. You've understood that perfectly. It's not a nice feeling, is it, when you want to make friends and it's not working out?

Now, can you remember *why* the monkey, the rabbit, and the frog didn't want to be friends with the elephant? Don't worry if you can't remember all the details, just tell me what you *do* remember. We can figure it out together!

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) The... the monkey... (looks up, eyes wide) ...was because... the elephant couldn't... swing! (Confidently) And the rabbit... (frowns, confused) ...uh... something about a hole? (Shrugs, voice getting quieter) I... I don't remember the frog. (Looks anxious) Was it wrong?

That's fantastic! You remembered the monkey and the swinging perfectly. See? You *do* remember! And you're right about the rabbit and the hole. The rabbit said the elephant was too big to fit in its burrow.

And don't worry at all about not remembering the frog. That's perfectly okay. The frog didn't want to be friends because the elephant couldn't jump.

Now, you did so well remembering those reasons. It sounds like those rejections really affected the elephant! How do you think the elephant felt after hearing all those "no's"? Take your time, and it's okay to guess.

(Eyes welling up slightly, voice trembling) Probably... (sniffles) ...really, *really* sad. (Wipes eyes quickly) Like... like nobody liked him. Even though... even though he just wanted to be friends. (Looks down, kicking the floor) It's... not nice when people say no.

Oh, sweetie, you've got such a kind heart. It's clear you really feel for the elephant. And you're absolutely right, it's a horrible feeling to be rejected when you just want to be friends.

Now, you've already told me how the elephant *felt*, which is wonderful. Let's think a little more about *why* the other animals said no. They each had a reason, didn't they? Do you think their reasons were fair? What do *you* think about why they didn't want to be friends with the elephant? Maybe thinking about whether their reasons were good ones will help us understand how the elephant felt even more. There are no wrong answers here, just what you think.

(Thinking hard, forehead furrowed) Uh... (hesitates) I think... maybe... (looks up, brow still furrowed) ...it wasn't very nice. (More confidently) Because... because just because the elephant couldn't swing... doesn't mean he couldn't be a good friend! (Eyes widen) Maybe he could tell funny stories! Or... or give good hugs! (Voice fades again) But... I don't think... (stammers) I don't think the monkey... even thought about that. (Looks down, sadly) It's like... they only wanted friends who were exactly like them.

You've put your finger on something *really* important there. It sounds like you think the other animals were being a little closed-minded, judging the elephant based only on what he *couldn't* do, instead of what he *could* offer as a friend. It takes a very thoughtful person to see that! You’ve really picked up on how unfair that was!

Okay, before we move on, could you just quickly tell me everything you've told me about the story so far, in your own words? That will help us keep everything straight in our heads. Don’t worry about getting every detail perfect, just the main points.

(Takes a deep breath, trying to remember) Okay... so... the elephant was lonely, and he wanted friends, but nobody wanted to be his friend because... because he couldn't swing, or fit in a hole, or jump. And that made him really sad. And... and it wasn't very nice of the animals, because they didn't even try to see if he could be a good friend in other ways. (Looks at teacher, anxiously) Is that... is that right?

That's perfect! You remembered all the important parts, and you explained it so clearly. You've really understood the first part of the story and the elephant's feelings. I'm so impressed with how well you're understanding everything. It's time for me to go now, but well done today, I really enjoyed talking to you!

We will acknowledge the student's correct answer ("sad," "lonely"). Then, we'll ask guiding questions, breaking down the story's events. ("Why do you think the animals rejected the elephant?"). This will likely take 2 utterances.

record.summary: The student established the elephant's initial sadness due to rejection, remembering the monkey's reason for refusal. They recalled the rabbit's reason partially. The student's body language suggests anxiety (fiddling, looking down) and emotional connection to the elephant's feelings (welling eyes, trembling voice).

The student understands the elephant's initial sadness and loneliness due to rejection. They recall the monkey's reason for refusal (swinging) and partially remember the rabbit's. The student empathizes with the elephant's feelings, showing sadness and anxiety. They articulate that the other animals' reasons were unfair and that friendship isn't about being the same.

The student summarised that the lonely elephant was sad because the monkey, rabbit and frog rejected him as he couldn't swing, fit in a hole, or jump. The student, looking down and fiddling initially, became more confident, but their voice trembled with empathy for the elephant. They recognised the animals' unfairness.

dialogue: Okay, so we have a story about a girl, an egg, a potato, and some tea. It sounds a bit like a riddle, doesn't it? What do you think this story is trying to tell us? What's the first thing that pops into your head when you think about it?

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... (long pause) ... it's about... things changing? (Eyes widen slightly, then dart around the room)

Like... the egg got hard... and the potato got soft? (Confused look) And the tea... made the water... tea? (Raises hand hesitantly) Is it... is it like... are people like that too? (Chews on lip nervously) Like... do we change when things are hard?

That's a fantastic start! You're absolutely right. It *is* about things changing, and you've already picked up on the most important changes in the story. You noticed how the egg, the potato, and the tea all reacted differently to the same situation – the boiling water.

Now, let's think about that for a moment. Why do you think the father used an egg, a potato, and tea? What do you think they represent *before* they went into the hot water? Just take a guess, there's no wrong answer here! Maybe the egg is strong, maybe it is fragile! What is your initial thought?

(Thinking hard, brow furrowed, tapping foot nervously) Um... (looks away, searching for an answer in the air)... well, the potato... it's kinda hard, right? (Points vaguely towards where a potato *might* be). So, maybe... (stutters) maybe it's like... someone who's tough... on the outside? (Eyes widen a little) But... but then the hot water... makes it soft.

(More hesitant) And the egg... it's... fragile? (Looks down at hands again) 'Cause it breaks easy? (Pulls at a loose thread on shirt) So... maybe it's someone who's... who's not very strong to begin with?

(Quietly) I... I don't know about the tea... (Looks up at teacher with a questioning gaze) That's a hard one. The tea just makes the water tea?

That's excellent! You've made some really insightful connections. The potato being tough on the outside and the egg being fragile – those are perfect observations. You're doing a wonderful job thinking about what they might represent. Don't worry about the tea just yet; we can come back to that.

For now, let's stick with the egg and the potato. You said the potato is like someone tough who becomes soft when things get hard. Can you think of a time when something like that might happen to someone? Maybe they seem strong, but inside they're actually feeling quite vulnerable? Just think of an example, real or make-believe, it is alright!

(Anxious look returns, nervously rubs hands together) Uh... (long pause, avoids eye contact) ... Like... maybe... (stutters) ...maybe a kid... (voice barely a whisper) ... a kid who... who acts like they don't care... if they get picked on... (swallows hard) ...but... but inside... they're really sad? (Looks down, tracing patterns on the floor with a shoe)

(Sighs softly) I... I don't know. Is that... is that right? It's just... hard to think about...

That's a really thoughtful example, and it's absolutely right! It shows you're understanding the story on a deeper level. You've described perfectly how someone can *seem* strong on the outside but be hurting inside, just like the potato. That takes real empathy, and you should be proud of yourself for making that connection. It *is* hard to think about sometimes, and it's okay to take your time.

Now, let's build on that. You've shown how the potato can represent someone who seems tough but is actually vulnerable. How about the egg? You said it's fragile to begin with. Can you think of a time when someone who *starts* feeling weak or fragile might react to a difficult situation? What might happen to them? Maybe they become stronger, maybe something else! Just take your time, and remember, any thought you have is a good one.

(Takes a deep breath, still looking down, but voice is a little stronger) Okay... um... (thinking hard, taps fingers on desk) ... so, the egg... it's fragile... and then it gets hard... (Eyes widen a little, a small smile appears)

So... maybe... (more confidently) ... maybe it's like... like someone who's scared... to try new things... 'cause they think they'll fail? (Looks up at the teacher briefly, then back down) But... but then they... they try something really hard... and they... they don't break? (Looks up again, a little more confidently) And then they're stronger? (Chews on lip again, but seems less anxious) Like... like they're not as scared anymore? 'Cause they know they can do hard things?

That's fantastic! You've really nailed it. Someone scared to try new things, then finding strength through overcoming a challenge – that's exactly what the egg represents. You've explained that beautifully.

Before we finish, could you quickly summarise everything you've told me about the egg and the potato so far? Just in your own words, so I know you've understood completely.

(Looks down, gathers thoughts, fidgets a little less now) Okay... so... (pauses) ... the potato... it's like someone who looks strong... but maybe they're not... really strong inside. (Looks up briefly) And when things get hard... they get... soft... or sad.

(Takes a breath) And the egg... it's like someone who's scared... or fragile... at first. (Smiles a little) But... but when things get hard... they can become stronger... and not be scared anymore. (Looks at teacher, a hint of pride in eyes) Did I... did I do it right?
You absolutely did it right! That was a brilliant explanation, and I'm so proud of how much you've understood and how well you've expressed yourself. Well done, and have a lovely rest of the day!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about this story! It's got some interesting characters, doesn't it? What did you think about the older brother at the beginning? Did he seem like a very happy person?

Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with hands) No, I don't think so. He... (hesitates) He was... mean? (peeks up at the teacher, then looks away again) He didn't seem very happy... he was... uh... wanting more.

That's a great start! "Wanting more" is a really good way to describe him. You're absolutely right, he was mean, and wanting more. Can you tell me *why* you think he was mean? Don't worry if you're not sure, just take a guess. Even a small idea is helpful!

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Um... because... (stuttering) he... he only thought about... him? (Looks up at the teacher, nervously) And... and he wasn't... nice to his brother. He wanted all the golden apples for himself. (Frowns a little) Was that... bad?

That's excellent! You're doing so well at understanding the story. Yes, that *was* bad. Thinking only about himself and not being nice to his brother *is* definitely mean. You've got a great understanding of what's happening!

Now, let's think a little more about *why* he only thought about himself. What do you think made him that way? It's a tricky question, but I know you can come up with some ideas! Maybe he was worried about something? Or maybe he just hadn't learned how to be kind yet? What do you think? There's no wrong answer, just try your best!

(Looks down at my shoes, scuffing them on the carpet) Uh... (pauses) Maybe... maybe he was... (takes a deep breath) ...scared he wouldn't have enough? (Looks up, eyes wide with worry) If he didn't sell enough wood, maybe he... wouldn't have food? (Voice gets quieter) My tummy gets rumbly when I'm hungry...

Oh honey, that's a *fantastic* idea! Being scared he wouldn't have enough is a *really* good thought. It makes perfect sense that he might be worried about food. You're so clever to think of that! It sounds like you understand what it feels like to be hungry.

Now, let's build on that a little. If he *was* scared of not having enough, do you think that gave him the *right* to be mean to his brother? Or do you think there might have been a better way to deal with his fear? Take your time, there's no rush.

(Shakes head slowly, looking down at hands again) No... (voice barely a whisper) He shouldn't be mean... (thinking hard, furrowing brow) He could... he could ask for help? Maybe... maybe his brother would share... (looks up, eyes sparkling with a new idea) Or... or they could chop wood together! Then they'd have more... and wouldn't be scared! (Claps hands softly)

That's brilliant! Asking for help, sharing, working together... those are all wonderful ideas! You've really thought deeply about this.

Okay, to make sure we've got everything clear in our minds, can you tell me *everything* we've said about the story so far, in your own words? Just a quick summary will do!

(Eyes dart around the room, a little panicked) Uh... (stuttering) Um... the brother... he was mean... because he wanted... more apples... and he was maybe scared... of being hungry... (takes a shaky breath) And he... he should have asked his brother for help... instead of being mean... (looks at the teacher, pleadingly) Did I... did I get it right?

You absolutely got it right! That's a perfect summary, honey. You explained the brother's actions *and* suggested better solutions. I am so impressed with how well you understood the story and the reasons behind everyone's actions! Remember, your ideas are valuable, and you have a wonderful way of understanding people. Keep that up! It's time for you to go now, have a great day.

dialogue: Hi there! That's a fun story, isn't it? Can you tell me in your own words what the fox was trying to do?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh… (clears throat) He… he wanted the… grapes. (Looks up quickly, then down again)
That's right! He wanted the grapes. Good job! What made those grapes so appealing to him, do you think?
(Thinking, scratches head) Uh… they were… purple? (Looks up, eyes wide) And… juicy? (Hesitates) I… I think he was… hungry. (Looks away, shyly)

Yes, you're absolutely right! He was hungry, and those big, purple, juicy grapes looked like the perfect snack. You're doing great! Now, the story says he "jumped as high as possible." What do you think that tells us about how much he wanted those grapes?
(Thinking hard, biting lip) Uh… A lot? (Looks at the teacher, unsure) Like… super much? He… he really, really wanted them? (Shrugs, looks down again)

You're exactly right! "Super much" is a perfect way to describe it! He really, really wanted them. And you're doing such a good job explaining this. Now, he keeps jumping, right? But what happens? Does he get the grapes easily?
(Shakes head) …No. (Looks up briefly) He… he couldn’t reach. (Frowns slightly)

Okay, you've explained everything so well so far. You've told me the fox was hungry, he really, really wanted the grapes, and he kept trying to get them but couldn't reach. Can you put all those pieces together and tell me the story in your own words, just up to the point where he can't get the grapes? Take your time, there's no rush at all.

(Stares at the floor, thinking. Starts to tap foot nervously) Uh… (Takes a deep breath) There was a… fox. And he was… really, really hungry. (Looks up, makes eye contact briefly, then looks down again) And he saw… some grapes. Big purple, juicy grapes. And he… he jumped. (Makes a small jumping motion with hand) But… he couldn’t get them. (Mumbles) He jumped… and jumped… and jumped…
That's a perfect summary! You've remembered all the important details and explained it so clearly. You should be really proud of yourself. Well done! I'll see you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the rose and the cactus! It's a really interesting one, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most?
(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... the part... (pauses, thinking) ...the part where the rose... needed water? (Looks up quickly, then back down)
That's a great observation! Why do you think the part where the rose needed water stood out to you? Take your time, there's no rush at all.
(Shrugs slightly) I don't know... (Thinking) Maybe... because she was... mean? (Looks up, eyes wide) And then... she needed help? (Hesitates) ...Uh... is that right?

Yes, that *is* right! That's a really insightful way to look at it. You're doing great! Can you tell me a little more about *why* you think the rose being mean *and then* needing help is important? What does it make you think about? Just think about it, and whatever comes to mind is perfect.

(Thinking hard, brows furrowed) ...Because... (pauses) ...if you're mean... (looks down) ...maybe nobody will... (stuttering) ...want to help you? (Looks up, worried) ...But the cactus *did* help her... so... (confused) ...why?

That's a *fantastic* question! You're really thinking deeply about this. It's okay to be confused; it's a tricky situation. The cactus helping the rose even after she was mean *is* surprising. What do *you* think might make someone act like that? Even a little guess is a great start!

(Thinking, tapping a finger on the table) ...Maybe... (looks up, hesitant) ...maybe the cactus... is... nice? (Wrinkles nose) ...But why would you be nice... to someone who wasn't nice to you? (Looks at you, seeking an answer) Is the cactus... *too* nice?

Okay, you've really untangled some tricky parts of this story! Before we wrap up, could you try to put all your thoughts together? Tell me, in your own words, what you think is the most important thing we've talked about regarding the rose, the cactus, and the meaning of the story? Just a quick summary of what you've been thinking.

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize thoughts) Okay... So... the rose... was not nice. And then she needed help. And the cactus... even though the rose was mean... helped her anyway... (pauses) ...So... maybe... (thinking hard) ...maybe it's important to be nice... even if other people aren't...? (Looks up, hopeful) Is that... like... the lesson?

Yes, that *is* like the lesson! You got it! It's about being kind even when others aren't, and not judging people based on how they look. You did an amazing job working through this story today! Have a wonderful day!

dialogue: Hi there! That's a fun story, isn't it? Can you tell me a little bit about what Molly did in the story? What was her job?
(Looks down, fiddling with my fingers) Uh... (hesitates) ...she... uh... milked cows? (Looks up quickly, hopefully) And... uh... sell it at the market? (Quietly) Is that right?
Yes, that's exactly right! You remembered the important parts. You're doing great! What did she *plan* to do with the money she earned?

(Looks away, thinking hard) Uh... (stutters) She... wanted to buy a... a chicken? (Looks back, confused) So she could get more... money? (Raises hand slightly) If she got more eggs? Is that how it works?

Yes, you're absolutely right! She wanted to buy a chicken so she could sell the eggs. That's very good thinking! You're understanding the story really well.

Now, what *else* did she imagine doing with all the money from the milk and the eggs? What was she dreaming about?

(Eyes widen a little, thinking beyond the story) Uh... (pauses, chewing on my lip) She... she wanted to make the other milkmaids... (searches for the word) ...envious? (Looks at the teacher, questioningly) Is that the right word? Because she would have so much money to buy... things?

Envious is a *perfect* word! You're understanding exactly how Molly was feeling. It sounds like you really get how she was imagining things. Now, what happened *after* she started dreaming about all this? What went wrong?

(Frowns, looks down at my hands) Uh... (stutters slightly) She... she spilled the milk? (Looks up quickly, a little worried) Because she was skipping? And... and she didn't get any money then? (Quietly) Did she?

That's right! She spilled the milk because she was skipping and got too excited. And no, she didn't get any money. You've picked up on all the important parts of the story so far.

Could you try to tell me in your own words what happened to Molly from the beginning to the end of her trip to market, including how she felt?

(Takes a deep breath, looks around the room) Okay... (frowns, trying to remember) She was going to sell milk... and she thought she would buy a chicken... (pauses) And then she'd have lots more money... And she'd make... (struggles for the word again) ...the other milkmaids... envious. (Looks down, tracing a pattern on the desk with my finger) And then she got too excited and... spilled the milk... and she didn't get any money. (Looks up, a little sad) She probably felt... bad?

You've done a fantastic job putting the whole story together and describing how Molly felt! You really understood her dreams and her disappointment. Well done! I'm so glad we could work on this together. Have a wonderful day!

dialogue: Hi there! That's a lovely little story about the owl. What part of the story did you find most interesting?
(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... (pauses) the part where... where the owl... heard stories? (Looks up quickly, then back down) I liked that part.
That's a great detail to focus on! It shows you're really thinking about the story. What kind of stories do you imagine the owl heard near his oak tree?

(Thinking hard, tapping my foot) Hmmm... Uh... (Stutters) Maybe... maybe stories about... (looks around the room) ... about the squirrels? (Looks back at the teacher, hopeful) Did the squirrels tell stories?
That's a wonderful idea! Squirrel stories! What makes you think the squirrels might have been storytellers?

(Thinking, furrowing my brow) Because... because they run around a lot! (Gestures wildly with my hands, then stops abruptly) And... and they see things! And... and maybe they tell each other about the things they see. (Looks at the teacher, a little unsure) Is that... is that a good idea?

That's a super idea! I love how you're thinking about the squirrels as little reporters, zooming around and collecting news. What kind of things do you think they might have seen that would be interesting enough to tell each other, or even the wise old owl?

(Looks up at the ceiling, pondering) Uh... (pauses) Maybe... maybe they saw... a little girl... (looks at my shoes) ... dropping her ice cream! (Looks up at the teacher, excitedly) And they tell all the other squirrels, "The little girl dropped her ice cream! Quick, get some before the ants do!" (Giggles a little)

Okay, that's brilliant! You've really brought the story to life with those storytelling squirrels. Now, before we go any further, can you try to summarise what we've said about the story so far, including the owl and the squirrels? Just tell me in your own words.

(Looks a bit overwhelmed, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Uh... (Long pause) The owl... he listened to stories. (Looks at the teacher for reassurance) And... the squirrels... they tell stories... about ice cream. (Looks down again) Is that... is that right?

Yes, that's a great start! You've remembered the most important parts. The owl listens, and the squirrels tell stories, especially about that very important ice cream incident! You're doing wonderfully! Now, I have to go, but keep thinking about the story and those busy squirrels! Bye!

(Looks a bit overwhelmed, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) Uh... (Long pause) The owl... he listened to stories. (Looks at the teacher for reassurance) And... the squirrels... they tell stories... about ice cream. (Looks down again) Is that... is that right?

Yes, that's a great start! You've remembered the most important parts. The owl listens, and the squirrels tell stories, especially about that very important ice cream incident! You're doing wonderfully! Now, I have to go, but keep thinking about the story and those busy squirrels! Bye!

This should take 2 utterances.

dialogue: Hi there! That's a really interesting story about the farmer and the goose. What part of the story stood out to you the most?
Uh… (looks away, fidgeting with my pencil) The… the golden egg? (pauses, thinking) Because… (thinking hard) … uh… it was… golden? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful smile)

That's a good start! The golden egg is definitely important. Can you tell me a little bit more about *why* you think the golden egg stood out to you? Maybe something about what it meant to the farmer?

(Thinking, tapping my foot) …Uh… (looks up at the ceiling) … It made him happy? (Looks back at the teacher, shrugs a little) … Because he could sell it? And… uh… buy stuff? (Pulls on my sleeve, looking down) Is that right?

Yes, that's absolutely right! The golden egg *did* make him happy because he could sell it and buy things. That shows you're understanding the story.

Now, thinking about that happiness... do you think the farmer was happy *enough* with just one golden egg a day? What makes you say that? Don't worry if you're not sure, just take a guess!

(Thinking, scratches my head) Uh… no? (Looks at the teacher, a little confused) Because… he cut open the goose? (Eyes widen slightly) He wanted… more? Is… is that greedy? (Looks down at my hands, fiddling with my fingers)

Yes, that's a very good observation! He *did* cut open the goose, and that tells us he wanted more.

And yes, wanting more *can* be greedy. You're doing a great job connecting the dots! Now, can you tell me *why* wanting more in this story turned out to be a bad thing for the farmer? Take your time, there's no rush!

(Thinking hard, pursing my lips) … Uh… (looks up at the ceiling) … Because… (pauses, looks back at the teacher, almost whispering) … the goose… died? (Frowns slightly) And then… no more eggs? (Looks at the teacher, questioningly)

You've got it! The goose died, and then there were no more eggs. You've picked up on some really important things about the story.

To make sure we're both on the same page, could you tell me everything you've told me about the story so far, in your own words? Just tell me what happened, and why it was a problem for the farmer.

(Takes a deep breath, looking down at my desk) Uh… the farmer… had a goose… that laid a golden egg. (Looks up, then quickly down again) And he was happy… but he wanted more. So… so he cut open the goose… (shivers slightly) …and the goose… died. (Looks at the teacher, a little sadly) And then… no more golden eggs. And he was… uh… (thinking) sad? Because he didn't have any more eggs to sell. (Quietly) Was… was that bad of him?

That's a *perfect* summary! You explained everything so clearly, and you're absolutely right, it *was* bad of him because he lost everything he had. You really understood the story. Well done! I'm so impressed with how well you did today. Have a wonderful day!

dialogue: Hello! That's a clever story, isn't it? Can you tell me in your own words what happened at the beginning of the story? What did the farmer and his neighbour do?

(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting)

Uh... (pauses) the farmer... uh... wanted water... (stuttering) for his farm... so he... um... bought the well? (Looks up quickly, hoping that's right) From the neighbour... yeah. But... but the neighbour... (thinking) ... uh... (looks away) didn't want him to take any water...

Yes, you're right, the farmer bought the well! That's a great start! You've remembered the most important part. And you're also right about the neighbour not wanting him to take water. Can you tell me why the neighbour didn't want him to take any water? What was the neighbour's reason? Don't worry if you're not sure, just take a guess!

(Scrunches up my nose, thinking really hard)

... (Long pause)..... Hmmm... (eyes light up a little) Was it... was it because... the neighbour was being... (searches for the word) ... tricky? (Looks at the teacher expectantly, hoping I used the right word. A small, polite smile appears) He wanted to keep the water for himself? But... but he already sold the well! That's not fair! (Frowns a little)

Yes, you're absolutely right! The neighbour *was* being tricky! You used the perfect word. And you're spot on – he wanted to keep the water for himself, even though he sold the well. That *isn't* fair at all! You're doing a fantastic job understanding the story. What happened after the farmer realised the neighbour was being tricky? Where did the farmer go?

(Looks down again, tracing patterns on the desk with my finger)

... Uh... (pauses) He... he went to... someone important? (Looks up, trying to remember) The... the... (struggling to find the word) ... the em...em...emperor? (Says the word slowly and hesitantly) He went to the emperor to... to say it wasn't fair? Because the neighbour was being tricky? (Looks at the teacher for confirmation, feeling a little more confident) Was that right?

Yes! That's exactly right! He went to the emperor. You remembered! And you're also right about *why* he went – because the neighbour was being tricky and it wasn't fair. You are following the story so well! What happened when the farmer told the emperor about the problem? What did the emperor do?

(Leans forward a little, showing more interest)

The... the emperor... (thinking) ...he had someone... someone who worked for him... a... a helper? (Looks up, questioningly). They asked the neighbour... why he didn't let the farmer have the water... (pauses, trying to remember the exact words) ... and the neighbour said... (eyes widen a bit, remembering the silly reason) ... he said he sold the *well*, but not the *water*! (Giggles softly, finding the neighbour's excuse a bit funny but also a little confusing).

That's brilliant! You remembered so many details! The helper is called a courtier, but "helper" is a great way to describe what he did. You explained the neighbour's silly excuse perfectly, too! You've really understood the first part of the story so well. Before we move on, can you quickly tell me everything you've said about the story so far, in your own words? Just a quick summary will do!

(Takes a deep breath, trying to organize my thoughts)

Okay... (thinking) The farmer... he bought a well from his neighbour to get water for his farm... but the neighbour was being tricky and didn't want him to have any water... so the farmer went to the emperor... and the emperor's helper... the courtier... asked the neighbour why... and the neighbour said he only sold the *well* not the *water* inside! (Looks up, a little out of breath, but proud of myself for remembering everything) Did I get it all?

Yes, you got it *all*! Absolutely perfect! You remembered every important detail and explained it so clearly. I'm so impressed! Well done! That's all for today; have a wonderful rest of the day; I'm really proud of you. Goodbye.

dialogue: Hello there! That's a lovely story about the lonely elephant. Can you tell me, in your own words, what the elephant was trying to do at the beginning of the story?
Uh... (looks away, fidgeting with fingers) The elephant... uh... was trying to... (thinking) ... to find... friends?
Yes, exactly! Finding friends. That's a wonderful start! You're doing great! Now, can you tell me *why* the elephant was looking for friends?
...(long pause, looks down at shoes)... Because he... (shrugs) ... was lonely? (looks up quickly, then back down)

Yes, that's right! He was lonely. You got it! That's a really good observation. Being lonely can be tough, can't it? Now, what happened when the elephant asked the *other* animals to be his friend? What did they say? Take your time, you're doing so well!
(Thinking hard, brow furrowed) They... they said... no? (Looks at the teacher, questioningly) Because he couldn't... uh... swing or jump... or fit? (Uses hands to gesture big size)

Yes, that's absolutely right! They all said no because he couldn't do the things they could do. You remembered all of that! High five! (Offer a high five). That was excellent! So, the elephant is feeling sad, right? What happens *next* in the story? What changed? You're doing such a fantastic job recalling the details!

(Hesitates, looks around the room, then back at the teacher, speaking a bit more confidently) Uh... then... everyone was... running? (Eyes widen a little) Because... tiger? (Looks at the teacher again for confirmation) Was the tiger being mean?

You're doing so wonderfully! Yes, everyone was running because of the tiger! Now, before we talk more about the tiger, can you quickly tell me everything that's happened in the story so far, in your own words? Just a quick recap! You've remembered so much already!

(Sighs softly, looks at the floor, then takes a deep breath and looks up, trying hard) Okay... (Counts on fingers) Elephant... lonely... wants friends... Monkey says no... Rabbit says no... Frog says no... (Pauses) Tiger comes... Everyone runs! (Beams, proud of remembering) Did I do it right?

You did it perfectly! Absolutely spot on! I am so proud of you. You remembered everything so well, and explained it all in your own words. Well done.

I have to go now, but I will see you again soon. Keep up the great work!

dialogue: That's a lovely story! What part of it stood out to you the most?
(Looks down at my shoes, shuffling them slightly) Uh... (hesitates) The...the tea, I think?
The tea is a great choice! What about the tea surprised you the most?
(Thinking, wrinkles forehead) Uh... (looks up at the teacher, eyes wide) That it changed the...the water? (confident nod) Not just...like...dissolving? Like when I put sugar in my juice?

That's a wonderful observation! It's definitely more than just dissolving.

Now, can you tell me why you think the tea changing the water is so important to the story? Don't worry if you are not sure, any thought is a good thought!

(Looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) Hmmm... (taps chin) Because... (pauses, thinking hard) ...because the tea didn't just change *itself*. The potato and the egg...they changed, but the water stayed the same. The tea... (eyes light up) ...the tea *changed* the water! (looks back at the teacher, proud) So...so it's like...the tea is better?

That's a *fantastic* way to put it! You're right, the tea didn't just change itself, it changed the water.

Now, how does that difference – the tea changing the water versus the potato and egg changing themselves – connect to the story's message about dealing with difficult situations? Just think out loud; there's no right or wrong answer!

(Fidgets with my hands, thinking hard) Uh... (looks down again) So... the potato... it was strong, right? And then... (stutters) ...and then it got weak. And the egg... it was soft... and then it got strong. But the tea... (brightens up) ...it made something *new*! (looks at the teacher, hopefully) So... it's like... when things are hard... we can become strong... or weak... or... we can make something new happen? Like... like make things better for everyone?

Absolutely! You've made incredible connections! You noticed how the potato and egg changed individually, while the tea transformed the water itself. You then brilliantly linked that to creating something new and potentially making things better for everyone during difficult times.

Now, to make sure we've captured all your insightful thoughts, could you summarise in your own words what we've discussed about the egg, potato, and especially the tea, and how they relate to dealing with tough situations?

(Takes a deep breath, trying to remember) Okay... (looks at the teacher for encouragement) So... the potato was hard, then it was soft. And the egg was soft, then it was hard. (frowns slightly) They changed, but...but they were still just...a potato and an egg. (smiles, remembering the tea) But the tea! The tea changed the water! It made the water...tea! (claps hands softly) So... when bad things happen... we can be like the potato and egg and just change ourselves... or... we can be like the tea and change things for... for everyone! (beams proudly) Did I do good?
You did wonderfully! You explained everything so clearly and thoughtfully. I'm very proud of how you understood the story. Keep thinking creatively and asking great questions! Have a fantastic day!

dialogue: Alright, let's talk about this story! It's a good one. What part of the story stood out to you the most?

Uh... (looks down at my shoes) The... the tree? (Shrugs)

It gave... apples. Golden apples. (Thinking) And then... needles. Lots of needles!

That's a great start! You remembered the golden apples and the needles. It can be a bit tricky to remember everything. What did you think about the *older* brother's reaction to the needles? He wasn't very happy, was he? What do you think he was feeling?

(Fidgets with my hands)

...Uh... mad? (Looks at the teacher with big eyes) He... he wanted more apples. But... owies! Needles are... not good. (Thinking hard) Maybe... greedy? Is that a... big word?

(Eyes light up a little)

He... he helped! (Smiling slightly) He took... all the... (Struggling to remember) ...the pokey things out! (Looks at the teacher, hopeful) He was... nice. Even when the other brother... wasn't.

That's right! He *did* help. You remembered that perfectly! And you're right, he was very nice, even when his brother wasn't. Why do you think he helped his brother, even after his brother had been mean to him? What made him do such a kind thing?

(Chews on my lip, thinking)

...Uh... (Looks away) Because... they are... brothers? (Tilts head) Maybe... he loves him? Even if... (Pauses, searching for the right word) ...even if he's... being... not nice?

That's a really thoughtful answer! "Love" is a very powerful word, and it's likely a big part of why he helped. You've said so many great things about the story. Could you try to put it all together for me? Tell me the story again, but this time, use all the words and ideas you've already shared.

(Takes a deep breath, looking a little nervous)

Okay... so... there were two brothers... and the... the mean one... found a tree! And the tree gave him... (Counts on fingers) ...golden apples! But he wanted more... he was... greedy! (Looks up at the teacher, relieved) Did I... did I do good?

dialogue: That's a fun story, isn't it? It's okay if you feel a bit unsure about it. Lots of stories have hidden meanings! Let's see if we can understand it together. What do you think the fox was feeling at the beginning of the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... (long pause) ...hungry? (Looks up quickly then down again)
Yes, he was definitely hungry! And because he was hungry, how do you think he would have felt when he saw the grapes? It's alright if you're not sure, just take a guess! You're doing great so far.

(Bites lip, thinking hard)

... Happy? (Voice barely above a whisper) ... 'Cause he found... food? (Looks at the teacher with wide, slightly worried eyes)
Happy is a wonderful word to use! He probably *was* happy for a moment, thinking he'd found food. But what happened when he tried to get the grapes? Did he get them easily?

(Shakes head slowly, avoiding eye contact)

...No... (Stuttering slightly) ...He... he couldn't... reach? (Looks down at shoes)

That's right! He couldn't reach them. And you said it perfectly, even though it might have felt a little tricky to say. It's okay to take your time!

So, the fox *really* wanted those grapes. He jumped and jumped, but could he get them no matter how hard he tried? What happened then? Did he keep trying forever, or did something else happen?

(Sighs softly, shoulders slumping)

... Gave up... (Mumbles) ...Went home... (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my shirt)

You've told me so many important things about the story already! You noticed how the fox was hungry, how happy he was to see the grapes, and how he couldn't reach them no matter how hard he tried. You also remembered that he eventually gave up and went home.

Could you try putting all of that together in your own words, to tell me the main parts of the story that we've talked about so far? It's okay if it's not perfect, just try your best.

(Anxious expression, starts to wring hands)

Uh... (Long pause, looking around the room nervously) ... Fox... hungry... (Swallows hard) ...Saw... grapes... happy... but... can't reach... (Voice trembling) ...Gave up... went home... (Looks down, almost whispering) ... Sorry...

That's absolutely perfect! You told me all the important parts of the story, even though it felt a little scary to do. You should be really proud of yourself! Remember, it's okay to take your time, and it's okay if it's not perfect. You did a fantastic job! Have a great day, and I'll see you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of the rose and the cactus. It seems like a sad story, right? What did you think about the rose at the beginning of the story?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my hands) Uh... the rose... (stutters) ...was... pretty?

(Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down) ...and... mean?

That's a really good start! Yes, the rose *was* very pretty, and you're right, she wasn't very kind. It takes courage to admit that someone is both beautiful *and* mean. Now, can you tell me *why* you think the rose was mean? Don't worry if you're not sure, any idea is a good idea!

(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) Uh... (looks away) ...because... she... said mean things? (Looks back at the teacher nervously) ...To the... cactus?

(Whispers) ...I don't like saying mean things...

That's absolutely right! She *did* say mean things to the cactus. And it's wonderful that you don't like saying mean things – that shows you're a very kind person. Now, let's think a bit more about *why* she said those mean things. The story says she would "take every opportunity to insult the cactus." Why do you think someone would do that? Even a guess is good! Maybe it made her feel better about herself? What do you think?

(Eyes widen a little, nervously glances around the room)

...Uh... (long pause)... Maybe... she wanted to... (stutters) ...feel... important? (Looks at the teacher with a hopeful expression, then quickly looks down again)

...Like... if she said the cactus was... ugly... she would be... prettier? (Voice barely audible) ...But that's... not nice...

You're doing *so* well! You've hit on something really important. It's true, sometimes people say mean things because they want to feel more important or better about themselves. And you're exactly right, it's *not* nice.

Now, let's think about the cactus for a moment. The story says the other plants tried to defend the cactus. How do you think the cactus felt when the rose was being mean, even though the other plants were trying to help? What do *you* think it's like to be in that kind of situation? Just tell me what comes to mind.

(Hugs myself tightly, shrinking a little in my chair)

...Sad? (Whispers) ...Lonely?

(Looks at the teacher with big, worried eyes) ...Like... nobody likes you? Even if... some people... try to help... it still... hurts?

(Voice cracks a little) ...Uh...

You've shared some really thoughtful ideas about the rose and the cactus. You've thought about why the rose was mean, and how the cactus might have felt. Could you try to put all of those thoughts together in a short summary? Just tell me everything you've been thinking about the story so far, in your own words. No pressure, just whatever comes to mind.

(Takes a deep breath, looking down at my hands)

...Okay... (Stutters) The rose... was pretty... but... she wasn't... nice... She said... mean things to the cactus... because... maybe... she wanted to feel... better... about herself...

(Pauses, thinking)

...And the cactus... was probably... sad... and lonely... even though... the other plants... tried to help... (Looks up at the teacher briefly) ...It still... hurts... when someone... is mean to you...

(Quietly) ...I don't like it when people are mean...

That's a *perfect* summary, you've understood the story so well! It's clear you've put a lot of thought and feeling into it, and I really appreciate you sharing those thoughts with me. Remember, kindness is always the best way. Have a wonderful rest of the day!

dialogue: Hello! That's a fun story, isn't it? Can you tell me, what did Molly do for work?
(Looks down, fidgets with hands) Uh... (hesitates) Milk... cow...

That's right! It had something to do with cows. Can you remember what animal Molly worked with? It's okay if you're not sure, we can figure it out together. What animals do you remember from the story?
(Eyes widen slightly, thinking hard) ... Uh... Chicken? (looks away nervously)
That's right, there was a chicken later in the story! But before the chicken, what animal did Molly take care of at the start of the story? It's okay if you need a moment to think!
(Bites lip, looks down at shoes) ... Uh... I don't... I don't know. (Voice is barely a whisper) Is it... is it a... a cow? (Looks up quickly, anxiously)
Yes! You got it! It *is* a cow! See? You knew it all along! Molly's job involved animals. What animal was that?

That's great! You've remembered that Molly's job was to milk cows and she thought about buying a chicken. You're doing so well! Can you tell me everything you remember about the story so far, from the beginning until now, in your own words? Don't worry if you miss something, just try your best.

(Eyes dart around the room, voice trembling slightly) Uh... Molly... milked cows... (pauses, thinking) ... and... (starts to fidget again) ...she wanted... chicken... (trails off, looking lost) ... I don't... I don't remember. (Almost whispers)

It's okay, you've remembered the most important parts! You know Molly milked the cows and wanted a chicken. That's a great start! We can stop here for today. Remember, it's okay to take your time and think things through. I'm very proud of you for trying your best! See you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the owl story! It's a short one, but it has a good message. What part of the story stood out to you the most? Don't worry if you're not sure, just tell me what you're thinking.
(Looks down at my shoes, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... (Stuttering) The... the owl... seeing things?
Okay, let's break down the owl's observations together. First, can you tell me *one* specific thing the owl might have seen near the oak tree? Think of something simple.
(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) ...Uh... a... a squirrel? (Looks up quickly, then down again)
That's a great start! A squirrel is perfect. Now, can you tell me what the squirrel might have been doing? Just a short, simple action.
(Hesitates, glances at the teacher, then back at my shoes) ...Uh... eating? (Voice barely a whisper)
Eating is good. Can you make that a little more specific? What was the squirrel eating? Maybe it was something special it found near the oak tree.
(Wrinkles my nose, trying to think) ... (Long pause)... An... an acorn? (Looks up, nervously) I... I don't know...

Okay, that's a good start. You said the owl saw a squirrel eating an acorn. That's great! Can you quickly put all of that together in one or two sentences? Just tell me everything you've told me about the story so far. Don't worry if it's not perfect!
(Looks away, nervously twisting my hands) ...Uh... the... the owl... saw a... a squirrel... (Deep breath) ...eating an acorn. (Voice trails off, sounding unsure)
That's a perfect summary! You remembered all the important parts. Well done! I am so proud of you. See you next time and keep up the good work!

dialogue: Okay, so we've read the story about the farmer and the golden goose. It's a bit of a sad story, isn't it? What part of the story made you feel a bit down?

(Fidgets with hands, looks down at desk)

Uh… (long pause) … when… when he… cut… the goose? (Voice cracks slightly) It was… uh… sad. (Looks away, avoids eye contact)

It's definitely okay to feel sad about that part. It *was* a sad thing that happened to the goose. You're very good at recognising those sad feelings!

Now, can you try to imagine for a moment... how do you think the goose *felt* when the farmer did that? It's alright if you're not sure, just give it your best guess.

(Eyes widen a little, chews on lip)

… uh… (shrugs shoulders slightly) … scared? (Looks back down at hands, picks at a loose thread on sleeve). I… I don’t… know… goose… feelings? (Voice trails off, almost a whisper)

That's a really good start! "Scared" is a perfect feeling for the goose to have in that moment. It shows you're thinking about things from the goose's point of view, and that's a really kind thing to do.

Now, let’s think a little bit more… If *you* were suddenly in a scary situation, like the goose, what else might you feel *besides* scared? Even a small word is great.

(Frowns, thinking hard, taps foot nervously)

… Uh… (Long pause, looks up at the ceiling) … mad? (Voice is very quiet, almost a question). 'Cause… 'cause it’s… not… fair? (Shifts in seat, uncomfortable)

That's excellent! "Mad" is a perfect feeling too, especially because you recognised it wasn't fair. You're doing so well thinking about this, even though it's a bit upsetting.

Now, let's try one more little feeling. Imagine something unfair happened to you, and you were also scared... would there be any other feeling mixed in there, even just a tiny bit? Maybe something like... confused?

(Looks down again, tracing patterns on the desk with a finger)

…(Quietly)… Confused… yeah… (Stuttering) …c-c-confused… why… why did he do it? (Sniffles quietly)

You've been so brave thinking about these hard feelings. You felt scared for the goose, mad because it wasn't fair, and confused about why the farmer would do such a thing.

Could you try to put all those feelings together and tell me, in your own words, what this part of the story makes you think about?

(Takes a deep breath, looks at the teacher briefly then away again, fiddling with a pencil)

… Uh… (Long pause, almost whispering) … Bad… bad to be… greedy? (Looks up quickly, then down again, anxious expression) 'Cause… 'cause… (struggling for words) … the goose… didn't do… anything… wrong… and… and… (trails off, unable to finish the sentence)

You've got it! You’re absolutely right. It *is* bad to be greedy, especially when it hurts someone who's done nothing wrong. You explained that so well, even though it was a difficult story. I’m really proud of how hard you worked today! Well done! See you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about this story! It sounds a bit tricky, doesn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most? Don't worry if you're not sure, just tell me whatever comes to mind!

(Fidgets with hands, looks down)

Uh… (pauses) … the… the farmer? (looks up quickly, then down again) … getting… getting the well?

(Warm smile, gentle tone)
That's a wonderful start! Focusing on the farmer is a great way to understand the story. Can you maybe try to think about what the farmer wanted? He bought something, didn't he? What was it, and why do you think he wanted it?

(Chews on lip, looking away)

…uh… the… the well? (Stutters) To… to… to get water? (Looks back at the teacher briefly, then back down, nervous) 'Cause… plants need water? (Voice trails off)

That's excellent! You remembered that the farmer bought the well and that he needed water for his plants. See, you *do* understand!

Now, let's break it down even more. Sometimes stories are easier when we think about them in small steps.

(Nods slowly, still looking down, fiddling with a pencil)

…Okay… (Quietly)

(Warm, encouraging tone, maintaining eye contact briefly before gently looking at the student's hands to reduce pressure)

That's right, "Okay" is all we need. Now, don't worry about the whole story, just one small action the farmer took. What's one little thing he *did* in the story? Even a tiny detail is perfect!

(Thinking hard, wrinkling forehead. Bites lip again.)

…Went… went to the… (long pause) … the big… the big guy? (Looks up, questioningly)

You’re absolutely right! He went to the “big guy.” That's a great way to put it. Now, before we go any further, could you just tell me everything you've said about the story so far, in your own words? Just a quick recap to help us keep track.

(Anxious look, fidgeting intensifies. Voice is barely a whisper.)

…Uh… (Stutters) … Farmer… bought… well… for water… plants… (Takes a deep breath, shaky) … and then… went to… big guy. (Looks down, ashamed) I… I don't… I don't know…

(Softly, with a reassuring smile, gently placing a hand on the student's desk near them, but not touching them directly) You know what? That's perfect! You've got the main parts, and you told it to me all by yourself. You explained that the farmer bought the well to water the plants and that he went to the big guy. That's excellent.

Remember, there's no need to be worried. You're doing a great job. I'm so glad you shared the story with me today. Have a wonderful rest of the day.

dialogue: Hello there! That's a lovely story about the elephant. It seems like the elephant was a bit sad at the beginning, wasn't it? Can you tell me why he was sad?

(Looks down at my shoes, fidgeting with my hands)

Uh... (pauses) ... he... uh... (long pause)

He didn't... um... (looks at the teacher with wide, nervous eyes) ... have... friends?

That's absolutely right! He didn't have friends, and it's okay to feel a little sad when you're lonely. You're doing great just telling me that!

Now, let's see if we can remember *who* he asked to be his friend first. Take your time... Who was the first animal the elephant talked to in the forest?

(Bites lip, looks away, thinking hard)

Uh... Was it... (stuttering) ... a... a... m-m-monkey? (looks back at the teacher, hopeful)

Yes, you got it! It *was* a monkey! You remembered that, even though it was a little tricky! I'm so proud of you for trying so hard!

Now, the monkey didn't want to be friends with the elephant. Can you remember *why* the monkey said no? It's okay if you don't remember exactly, we can figure it out together! What do you think a monkey likes to do?

(Looks down again, shuffling feet)

...Uh... (long pause) ... swing? (Peeks up at the teacher) Monkeys... swing?

Yes, you're absolutely right! Monkeys *do* love to swing! And that's exactly why the monkey didn't want to be friends with the elephant. The elephant was too big to swing in the trees, wasn't he? You remembered that the monkey likes to swing, that's fantastic!

See? You *do* remember the story! Even if it feels a little hard, you're getting it! Now, who did the elephant ask *next* to be his friend? Don't worry if you can't remember, just take a guess! You're doing so well!

(Thinking hard, eyes darting around the room)

(Whispers) Rabbit? ... Uh... (Looks at the teacher, nervous) ... Rabbit? Was it a rabbit?

Yes! It was a rabbit! You're doing so well remembering the story! You were a little nervous, but you got it right! That makes me so happy!

Now, before we run out of time, can you quickly tell me everything you remember about the story so far? Just a quick summary! You can do it!

(Looks down, fidgeting, voice very quiet)

Elephant... sad... no friends... monkey... swing... rabbit... (trails off, looks up at the teacher, pleading) ...I... I don't know...

It's okay! You remembered so much already! Elephant sad, no friends, monkey and the swing, rabbit... that's a *fantastic* start! We're out of time now, but you did so well today! Don't worry about not remembering everything perfectly, you're learning! Keep practicing, and I'll see you next time! Bye!

dialogue: That's an interesting story, isn't it? What part of it jumped out at you the most?
(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting with my fingers) Uh... (Long pause) ...the...the egg?
What *color* is the egg after it's boiled?
(Stuttering) Uh... wh-white? (Looks at the teacher nervously)
Good. And before it was boiled, what color was it?
(Thinking hard, eyes darting around the room) ...Um... light... brown? (Sounds unsure)
Okay, let's just think about the egg. Is the egg *hard* or *soft* after it's boiled?

Okay, you're doing great! You remember the potato was hard then soft, and the egg was soft then hard. You also remembered the egg's color and that the tea changed the water. Now, can you put all of that together and tell me, in your own words, what happened in the story so far? Don't worry about getting it perfect, just try your best.
(Shuffles feet, avoids eye contact) Uh... (Long pause) The girl was sad... and the dad... he... he boiled things... (trails off). Uh... I... I don't know. (Voice barely audible)

It's okay. You remembered a lot of important things! Maybe thinking about being sad makes it harder to talk about. The story is about how things change when they face something difficult, just like the egg, the potato, and the tea. But don't worry if it's tricky to explain right now. You did a good job remembering the details. We can talk about it more another time. Bye for now!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about this story! It's a bit sad at the beginning, isn't it? What do you think about how the older brother treated his younger brother? It's okay if you feel a bit bad about it; it wasn't very nice, was it?

(Fidgets with hands, looks down at desk)

Uh... (pause) no. It wasn't nice. (Quietly) He... he was mean. (Shrugs, avoids eye contact) I... I wouldn't do that.

That's a great start! You're absolutely right, he *was* mean. It takes courage to admit when something isn't right.

Now, can you tell me *how* he was mean? What did he *do* that made him a mean brother? Don't worry if you can't remember every single detail; just tell me anything that comes to mind.

(Eyes widen slightly, chews on lip)

Umm... (long pause, looks at the ceiling) He... (Stuttering) He... he didn't... share? (Quick glance at the teacher, then back down at hands). And... and he was... mean... to him. (Whispers) I... I don't remember... all of it. (Voice trails off)

That's perfectly okay! You remembered that he didn't share, and that's a really important point. You're doing great. It can be tricky to remember everything, and that's why we're going through it together.

Now, let's think about *where* the older brother worked. He chopped something down... Do you remember what it was he chopped, and where he did it? Maybe that will help us remember some other mean things he did. Take your time, there's no rush at all.

(Thinking, taps foot nervously)

...Uhm... Wood? (Looks up at the teacher questioningly) He chopped wood... in the... the... (eyes dart around the room, whispers) ...forest? He sold it... at the... (long pause) ...market? (Sounding unsure)

Is that... right?

Yes! That's absolutely right! He chopped wood in the forest and sold it at the market. You remembered perfectly! See? You know more than you think you do!

Now, remembering that he went to the forest to chop wood... do you remember what happened *in* the forest that was a bit magical or unusual? It's okay if it's just a little piece of what happened. Anything you can remember about the forest will help us.

(Eyes flicker nervously, fidgets with a loose thread on shirt)

...Tree? (Whispers) A special... tree? (Looks down again, almost inaudible) It... it talked? (Frowns, trying to remember)

Yes! A special tree that talked! You remembered that perfectly! That was a very unusual thing to happen, wasn't it? You're doing so well to recall that.

Now, what did the tree *say* when the older brother was about to chop it down? Don't worry if you can't remember the exact words, just tell me what the tree wanted. What did it want the older brother *not* to do? Think about why a tree might not want to be chopped down. We'll figure it out together, bit by bit.

(Bites lip, wrinkles brow in concentration)

...Don't... chop? (Looks up, pleadingly) It... it didn't want to be chopped! (Voice a little louder) And... and it gave him... things? Shiny... things? (Hesitates) Was it... gold?

That's excellent! "Don't chop!" is exactly right! And you remembered the shiny things! You're doing wonderfully well piecing this together.

Now, before we go any further, could you tell me everything you remember about the story so far, just in your own words? It's okay if it's not perfect, just tell me what you remember. It will help us to see where we are up to and what we might need to think about next.

(Takes a deep breath, looks at the desk)

Okay... (Long pause) There were... two brothers. The older one... was mean. He chopped wood... in the forest. And then... he found a tree. A talking tree! And the tree... didn't want to be chopped. It... it gave him shiny things... gold things! (Looks up briefly, then back down) I... I think that's all I remember... so far. (Fidgets more) Am I... doing okay?

You are doing absolutely wonderfully! That’s a perfect summary. You remembered all the important parts! You should be so proud of yourself. Remember, stories are like little adventures in our minds, and you've explored this one brilliantly. Now, it's time for a break. I'll see you next time, and we can explore another story then!

dialogue: Hi there! That's a fun story about the fox and the grapes, isn't it? Can you tell me a little bit about what you think happened in the story? Just in your own words.
(Looks at the ground, shuffles feet) Uh... (pause) ...the fox... wanted grapes. (Looks up quickly, then down again) ...Big... purple... grapes.
That's right! Big, purple grapes. They sound delicious! What do you think the fox did next?
(Thinking, taps foot on the floor) ...Jumped? (Looks at you briefly, then back at the floor) ...Uh...jumped high?
Yes, you're absolutely right! He jumped. And you said he jumped high. He really wanted those grapes, didn't he? What happened when he jumped high? Did he get them?
That's a tricky situation for the fox! Since he couldn't reach them the first time, what do you think he tried then?

You've told me lots of great things about the fox and the grapes. Can you put it all together for me? Tell me the whole story, in your own words, from beginning to end, just like you're telling it to a friend.

(Looks down, draws circles on the floor with shoe.) Uh… (long pause) Fox...hungry. Sees…grapes. (Points vaguely upwards) Big ones! Tries to… jump. (Shakes head slightly) Can't… get them. (Looks up, then quickly down again) Goes…home. (Quietly) Grapes…sour.
That's a wonderful way to tell the story, you remembered everything so well! You really understand what happened to the fox. Keep practicing telling stories, you're doing great! Have a lovely day.

dialogue: Hi there! That's a lovely story. Can you tell me, in your own words, what happened at the beginning of the story? Who are the characters we meet first?

Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with hands) There was... uh... a rose... and a... cactus... (pauses) in the desert.

And... (eyes dart around the room) the rose... wasn't... nice.

That's a great start! You remembered the main characters and where they lived. And you're right, the rose wasn't very nice. Can you tell me a little bit more about *how* the rose wasn't nice? What did it *do*? Take your time, no rush at all. You're doing wonderfully!
(Looks at the teacher briefly, then back down at hands) Uh... it... (long pause, chewing on lip) said mean things... to the cactus. (Whispers) About how it looked. (Looks away again)

That's excellent! You remembered that the rose said mean things to the cactus about how it looked. That's a really important detail. You're doing a fantastic job remembering the story. Can you tell me, what did the other plants do when the rose was being mean? You're doing so well, keep going!
(Shrugs slightly, avoids eye contact) Uh... they tried... to help? (Tilts head, unsure) The cactus, I think. But the rose... didn't listen. (Mumbles) It liked... being mean.

That's great! "They tried to help" is exactly right. You remembered that the other plants weren't happy with how the rose was behaving. And you're absolutely right, the rose didn't listen to them; it liked being mean. You're doing a fantastic job remembering all these details! What happened then? What happened when summer arrived and it got really, really hot?

(Thinking, taps fingers on the desk) Uh... summer... (eyes widen slightly) It got... hot. (pauses) Really hot. And... (looks at the teacher hesitantly) the rose... (stuttering) ...it started to... wither? (Looks down again, waiting for confirmation)

Yes, that's right! The rose started to wither because it was so hot. You're remembering the story so well! You've told me so much already. Before we go on, can you just tell me everything that's happened in the story so far, in your own words? Just a quick summary to make sure we've got it all clear. You can do it!

(Sighs softly, but tries) Okay... (counts on fingers) There's a rose and a cactus in the desert. The rose is mean to the cactus 'cause it's prettier. The other plants try to stop the rose. Then it gets super hot in the summer. And the rose starts to... wither... (Looks up briefly, then down again)
That's a perfect summary! You got all the important parts. Well done! I'm so glad you shared this story with me today. You did a wonderful job! See you next time!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of Molly the milkmaid. What did Molly do for work?
Uh... (looks down at my shoes) ...milk... cows? (quietly)
Yes, she milked cows! That's right! And what did she do with the milk? You're doing great!
(Shrugs shoulders) ...Sell it? (looks at the teacher briefly, then back down)
Yes, sell it! You got it! So, she's walking to the market to sell the milk... what does she start thinking about? What's on her mind as she's walking?
...Money? (stutters slightly) Uh...buying things? (looks away, fiddling with my fingers)
Exactly! Money and buying things! You're absolutely right! What *specific* thing does she think about buying *first*? Take your time, you're doing wonderfully!
(Thinking) ...Uh... a...chicken? (looks up at the teacher, then quickly back down) ...to get more...money?

That's perfect! You've got all the important pieces! Before we move on, can you just tell me everything you've said about the story so far, in your own words? Just a quick little summary to make sure we're on the same page. You can do it!

(Hesitates, looks at the floor, then back at the teacher, then back at the floor) ...Okay... (takes a deep breath) ...Molly...milks...cows... and sells the milk... Then she wants... money... so she buys a...chicken... (looks up at the teacher, pleadingly) ...Is that right?
Yes, that's a great summary! You've remembered all the important details. Well done! I'm so proud of you for working through the story. Have a wonderful day!
