(I stroke my imaginary beard, looking down at "Midas" thoughtfully. I pause for a beat, letting the excitement hang in the air)

Hmmmm… (I drag the 'm' out) Shiny things *are* pretty cool. A golden car, you say? (I snap my fingers) Now *that's* an idea! And ALL the candy? A playground bigger than… well, bigger than Mount Olympus itself? (I chuckle) You almost have me convinced, Midas!

But… (I hold up a finger) Let's just say, hypothetically, you've got that golden car. Vroom, vroom! You're driving to get that mountain of candy. You get a little… peckish. What do you do? Show old Dionysus what happens next! Remember, you've got the golden touch! Play it out for me, King Midas! Show, don't tell!

(Beaming, claps hands together) Okay, okay! (Runs back a little to get some space, then pretends to drive a car, making 'vroom vroom' noises. Then, pretends to be hungry, rubbing tummy)

Okay, so... I'm driving (vroom vroom!), and I'm hungry! (Reaches into imaginary car, pulls out an imaginary apple). Mmm, apple! (About to bite into it, but stops suddenly, looking confused). Uh oh... (Looks down at the imaginary apple, then back at the teacher, stuttering) I... I touch it... (Slowly pretends to touch the apple) and... it turns to gold! (Looks really sad now. Voice gets very quiet) I can't eat it... (Looks away)

(I nod slowly, watching "Midas'" face carefully. I let the sadness hang in the air for a moment. Then, I clap my hands together, but not too loudly, as if to gently break the spell.)

Alright, King Midas! Excellent acting! You REALLY sold that "sad about the golden apple" bit! (I give a small, encouraging smile). So tell me, oh wise and powerful ruler... (I pause, tilting my head) Is that golden touch looking quite so shiny now? Is turning EVERYTHING to gold *still* the best idea EVER? Hmmm? Think about that apple. And tell old Dionysus... what else might Midas be missing out on? What OTHER things can't you do if everything you touch turns to gold? Let's hear those royal thoughts!

(Looks down at the ground, scuffing shoe. Frowning. Thinking really hard, then looks up)

No... (Voice is quiet, but more confident this time). It's not so shiny anymore. (Thinks some more. Uses a more complex sentence) Because if everything is gold, then you can't... you can't really *use* it, can you? (Asks a question to the teacher to confirm)

(Thinking beyond the golden apple) And... (starts to fidget) You can't... you can't hug your friends! (Voice cracks a little) Or... or play with your toys! (Looks at the teacher, almost pleadingly) They'd all turn to gold, and they wouldn't be fun anymore! (Starts to think about it more deeply) And... and even if you had all the candy in the world, you couldn't eat it! (Looks really bummed out) It's... it's like having... (struggling to find the right word) a REALLY big, shiny... problem! (Nods slowly, understanding)

(I smile gently, nodding encouragingly at the student's insights. Their face, once bright with excitement, now reflects a thoughtful understanding.)

You've really been thinking hard, haven't you? That's brilliant! You've taken us on a real journey with King Midas, from shiny gold dreams to a very "big, shiny problem"! So, before we wrap things up, could you put all of that together for me? In your own words, can you tell me what you think this story is *really* about? What's the big idea that King Midas is learning?

(Looks at the teacher, takes a deep breath. Seems nervous but determined)

(Organizing thoughts more carefully this time) I think... I think the story is about... (pauses, looking for the right words) wanting too much. (More confidently) Like, King Midas wanted all the gold, but he didn't think about what he would lose. (Thinking beyond the surface) He only thought about the shiny part, not the... the important part. (Looks at the teacher, seeking confirmation) And... and sometimes, the things that seem really good, like having all the gold, aren't really good if you can't... (struggling to express the feeling) if you can't share them or enjoy them with the people you love. (Looks down for a moment, then back up with a small smile) So... it's better to be happy with what you have, right? (Confidently) It's better than having everything turn to gold!

Absolutely! You got it! (Beaming with pride) You took that story, shook it all about, and figured out exactly what makes it tick! It *is* about wanting too much, and forgetting about all the wonderful things we already have. You really understood that Midas was so busy chasing shiny gold, he missed out on all the *real* treasures around him – like yummy food, fun toys, and hugs from his daughter! And you're completely right, it *is* better to be happy with what you have! You are a super star!

Alright, my brilliant storyteller, that’s all the time we have for today. You were fantastic! Keep thinking, keep questioning, and keep reading awesome stories! Bye for now!

record.strategy_description: Okay, with a highly extroverted student, I'll use playful role-play to explore the story's details. I can pretend to be Dionysus and playfully challenge the student (as Midas) about his wish, prompting them to describe the consequences he faced. This would likely take 2 utterances.

record.summary: The student is enthusiastic about the story, particularly the golden touch, imagining its possibilities (shiny things, golden car, candy). However, the student also recognises the downside when prompted, realising food would turn to gold. They demonstrate this understanding through roleplay, becoming sad when pretending to turn the apple to gold. Their body language conveys excitement and then disappointment.

The student excitedly recounted Midas turning everything to gold, captivated initially, but then saddened by the inability to eat or help his daughter. Playing Midas, the student eagerly listed the benefits (shiny things, riches), then grasped the consequences (inedible food). The student's initial excitement shifted to sadness, body language mirroring understanding.

The student, initially excited by the golden touch, focused on its superficial appeal. Through role-play, they realised the downsides - inability to eat or enjoy simple pleasures like hugs. Initially bouncy, they became pensive, scuffing their shoe and speaking quietly as they grasped the story's deeper meaning. They understood the dangers of wanting too much, concluding happiness lies in contentment.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's quite a wild ride, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to *you* the most?

(Eyes widen, bouncing slightly in my seat) Oh! Oh! I know! The part where… where everything turns to gold! (Beams, then fidgets with my hands) He touched the… the table! And it was all shiny! (Looks away, nervous) Was… was that okay? Was that what I was supposed to say? It was super cool! He got his wish! (Voice trails off, a little anxious) But then… then something bad happened, right? (Looks back at the teacher hopefully)

That's fantastic! You're absolutely right, the golden touch is definitely the most eye-catching part. And yes, it *was* super cool at first! You noticed exactly the right thing.

Now, you mentioned something bad happened after he touched the table. What do you remember happening *after* everything started turning to gold? Take your time, and don't worry about getting it perfect. Just tell me what you remember.

(Chews on lip, tapping foot) Um… after the table… (looks down at my hands, then back up) He… he wanted to eat! (Eyes get big again) But… but the food turned into gold too! (Wrinkles nose, a little disgusted) Yucky! I wouldn't want to eat gold! Would you? (Pauses, voice gets quieter) And then… (Stutters) th-then his daughter… she… she turned into gold too! (Looks down again, fiddling with my shoelaces) That was… that was sad. Very, very sad. (Sniffles softly)

You’re doing so great! See? You remembered all the important parts, even the sad ones. It *is* very sad when his daughter turns to gold. You have a good heart to feel that sadness.

Now, let's think about the *order* of events. You said he turned the table to gold, then he tried to eat, and *then* his daughter turned to gold. Is that right, or did something else happen in between? Remembering the order can sometimes help us understand why things happened.

(Furrows brow, thinking hard) Hmm… (Taps a finger on the desk, distracted by the sound) Table… food… (Eyes dart around the room) Oh! (Snaps fingers) I think… I think he was happy first! Really, really happy! He was like, "Yay! Gold!" (Pumps fist in the air excitedly, then deflates a little) But then he got hungry. (Grumbling noise) And *then* his daughter. So, happy, then hungry, then… sad daughter. (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Is that right? Did I get it right this time? (Voice is a little shaky)

Yes, you got it exactly right! Happy, then hungry, then the sad daughter. That's perfect! You are thinking so clearly about the story!

Now, let's think about why he was happy at first. Why did Midas want everything to turn to gold? What did he think having the golden touch would *give* him? Don’t worry if you are not sure, just take a guess!

(Eyes light up again) Gold is shiny! (Giggles) And… and it's worth lots of money! (Counts on fingers) One, two, three… lots and lots of money! He wanted to be rich! (Looks at the teacher, bouncing in seat again) He thought it would be fun to have all the gold! (Pause, then voice drops slightly) But… but it wasn't fun, was it? (Worried expression)

You're absolutely right! It wasn't fun at all. You understood that even though Midas *thought* being rich would make him happy, it actually made him very unhappy. You've remembered so many important things about the story.

Can you try to put it all together for me? Tell me everything you remember about Midas, from the beginning to the sad end, in your own words. Don't worry about being perfect, just tell me the story as you remember it!

(Takes a deep breath, looking a bit overwhelmed) Okay… okay… (Fidgets with hands, looks at the floor) King Midas… he helped someone… a… a funny man? (Looks up at the teacher for confirmation, then quickly looks down again) And then the wine man… the wine god… said he could have a wish! (Voice gets a little louder, more excited) And Midas wished that everything he touched would turn to gold! (Beams) He touched the table and… and it was all golden! Shiny! But then he was hungry, and the food turned to gold, and he couldn’t eat! (Frowns, remembering the bad part) And then his daughter… she hugged him, and she turned into gold too! (Voice cracks, almost tearful) And then he was sad because he couldn’t eat and his daughter was a statue. (Looks at the teacher, eyes wide and a little watery) It was a very bad wish. (Whispers) I wouldn't want that wish.

That was a brilliant retelling of the story! You remembered every important part, even the sad bits. I am so impressed with how well you understood the story of King Midas! Well done, you've worked really hard, so I think it's time to finish now - goodbye!

record.strategy_description: Okay, let's break it down gently. First, acknowledge their enthusiasm and affirm their contribution is valuable. Then, guide them by asking specific questions ("What happened *after* the table turned to gold?"). This'll take 2 utterances, building confidence and easing anxiety.

record.summary: The student recalls Midas turning objects, including a table, into gold and expresses excitement. They also remember the food turning to gold and the sadness of his daughter's transformation. The student is initially enthusiastic, but becomes anxious, fidgety, and seeks reassurance from the teacher.

The student recalls Midas turning objects to gold, focusing on the table and food. Initially excited (eyes widening, bouncing), they become anxious (fidgeting, shaky voice) when recalling the daughter's fate. They correctly identify the sequence of events: initial happiness, then hunger, and finally, the daughter's transformation.

The student recalls Midas turning the table to gold, struggling to eat golden food, and his daughter's tragic transformation. They fidget, look away nervously, and display excitement when recalling the 'shiny' gold, but become sad and tearful when discussing the daughter's fate.

dialogue: Hi! That's a really interesting story about King Midas. It sounds like he got himself into a bit of a pickle, didn't he? Can you tell me in your own words what happened at the beginning of the story? What good thing did Midas do?

(Wiggles excitedly in my seat, hand shoots up) Oh! Oh! I know! I know! (Bounces leg)

King Midas... umm... (looks away, thinking hard) He... he helped someone! A... a funny man! (Sticks tongue out trying to remember). A Satyr! Yeah! He was nice to him! And then the... the wine guy... (giggles) ...gave him a wish! (Looks at the teacher, beaming) Is that right? Was it the wine guy?

"The wine guy!" (I clap my hands and pretend to think hard) Hmmm, let's see... the *wine* guy, Dionysus... that's right! He did give Midas a wish. Now, if *you* were the god of wine and someone did you a HUGE favour, what kind of wish do *you* think you'd grant? Something super boring, or something... (I widen my eyes with a playful grin) ...extra sparkly and amazing?

(Eyes widen, leans forward eagerly) Something sparkly and amazing! Ooooh! Like... like the power to fly! (Flaps arms) Or... or a HUGE mountain of candy! (Starts counting on fingers, then gets distracted by fingers) Wait... what was the wish King Midas got? It was... shiny! (Confidently) He got to turn things into gold! Everything he touched turned into gold! (Looks very pleased with himself)

"Gold! That's right! (I make a 'ding ding ding!' sound effect like a game show). So, if *we* had the power to turn things into gold, what's the *very first* thing YOU would turn to gold? A toy? Your desk? (I look around the room with exaggerated curiosity). Think carefully! This is a *very* important decision!" (I pause, giving the student a chance to think and build suspense).

(Eyes dart around the room, then focus on shoes) My... my shoes! (Giggles) Golden shoes! (Looks down at shoes, imagining it) Then I could run *super* fast! (Starts to get out of seat) Can I go run now? With golden shoes? (Forgets question and starts miming running) Whee!

(I clap my hands together, feigning excitement) "Golden shoes! Super speed! That sounds AMAZING! But... (I scratch my head thoughtfully) ...if EVERYTHING you touched turned to gold, even by accident... what might happen when you wanted to, say... eat a yummy snack?" (I make a playful 'nom nom nom' sound effect and rub my tummy).

(Stops running, face scrunches up in thought). Oooooh... (Looks down at hands, then back up at teacher, worried). Uh oh... the snack would turn to gold too? (Makes a sad face). Then I couldn't eat it? (Stomach rumbles loudly). I *am* kinda hungry...

(I nod encouragingly, my eyes sparkling with warmth) "Exactly! You're catching on quick! It sounds like King Midas had a similar problem in the story. Now, in your own words, can you tell me everything that's happened to Midas so far? From the very beginning to his empty tummy?"

(Looks away, fiddling with shirt buttons). Ummm... (Counts on fingers, but loses track after one). Okay, okay! Midas helped the funny Satyr guy. Then the wine guy - Dionysus - gave him the gold touch! (Beams proudly). And at first, it was really, really cool! (Gestures excitedly with hands). But then... then he got hungry! And everything turned to gold! So he couldn't eat! (Looks glum. Starts to pick at a loose thread on shirt). That's all I remember.

That’s a fantastic recap! You remembered the important parts perfectly. Don't worry about forgetting little bits, the most important thing is that you understood the story and why Midas wasn’t so happy in the end! You did so well today, superstar! Now, off you pop, and remember to be kind! See you next time!

record.summary: The student knows that King Midas helped a Satyr, which led Dionysus to grant him a wish. The student correctly recalls Midas wished for the golden touch. The student is enthusiastic and excitable, wiggling, bouncing their leg, and flapping arms while speaking.

The student excitedly recounted Midas' good deed for a Satyr, leading Dionysus to grant him a wish.  The student accurately recalled Midas wishing for the golden touch, demonstrating understanding and enthusiasm through wiggling, hand-raising, leg-bouncing and beaming.

The student recalls Midas helping a Satyr, leading Dionysus to grant him the golden touch wish. Initially excited, the student understands the consequence of Midas being unable to eat. The student is enthusiastic, bouncing and gesturing, but gets distracted and loses focus, needing prompting. There is also evidence of being worried at not remembering everything.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a pretty interesting one, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to *you* the most?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my fingers)

Uh... (pauses) The... the part where... everything turned to gold? (glances up nervously)

That's a great starting point! It *is* quite a moment when everything starts turning to gold. What *kind* of things did he turn to gold first, do you remember? Don't worry if you're not sure, just take a guess! It's okay if it's not perfect. We can figure it out together.

(Thinking hard, bites lip)

... Uh... (looks around the room, distracted by a colorful poster) ... Was it... like... his chair? And... and stuff? (eyes widen slightly, then looks down again) I think so. (mumbles) I... I don't remember *all* of it... (anxious expression)

That's right! It *was* probably his chair, and other things like that! You have a good memory! Now, after touching some of his things, what happened *next* in the story? Take your time... maybe thinking about what Midas *wanted* might help you remember?

(Eyes dart around nervously)

... He... he wanted to... (hesitates) ... to eat? (voice barely a whisper) And... and he couldn't? Because... because it was all... gold? (looks up, a flicker of understanding in their eyes) And then... then his daughter...? (face scrunches up, close to tears) Oh no...

Yes, you're doing wonderfully! You *absolutely* remembered that he couldn't eat because everything turned to gold, and you're right, it *is* a sad story.

It seems like you're feeling the sadness of the story, and that's okay. Sometimes stories *do* make us feel things.

Now, before Midas couldn't eat and before... before his daughter... do you remember if anyone *warned* him about the golden touch? Someone tried to tell him it might not be such a good idea. Can you remember who that was? It's alright if you don't! We can think about it together. Maybe knowing *who* warned him will help us understand *why* it was a bad idea.

(Sniffling quietly, wipes eyes with the back of their hand)

... Dionysus? (looks up, a question in their eyes) The... the wine guy? (uses a more complex word, proud for a moment) He... he said it wasn't good? But... (brows furrow in confusion) But Midas didn't listen? Why didn't he listen? (anxious again, chews on fingernail) Was he... was he silly?

You're doing *so* well, and it's great that you remembered Dionysus and that Midas didn't listen to him. It sounds like you're really connecting with the story! Before we talk more about *why* Midas didn't listen, could you try to tell me *everything* you remember about the story, just in your own words? Don't worry about getting it perfect, just tell me what you remember from the beginning to the end. It will help us put all the pieces together!

(Takes a deep breath, looks away, trying to organize thoughts)

Okay... (pauses) King Midas... he helped... (struggles to remember the word) ...a Satyr. And then... the wine god, Dionysus, said he could have a wish. And Midas... (voice gets softer) ...he wished for everything to turn to gold. Dionysus said no! But he did it anyway. (eyes well up again)

And then... (voice cracks) ...he touched everything and it turned to gold! And he was happy... for a little bit. But then he was hungry. And... and he couldn't eat. And then his daughter... (sobs quietly) ...turned into gold too! And... and he was sad. (looks at the teacher, pleadingly) It was a bad wish! (sniffles) He should have listened!

You’ve done an amazing job remembering the whole story, and it's okay to feel sad about it. It *was* a bad wish, and you're right, he should have listened. You really understood the story and how Midas felt. I'm so proud of you for working so hard! Have a good day, and I'll see you next time!

Yes, you're doing wonderfully! You *absolutely* remembered that he couldn't eat because everything turned to gold, and you're right, it *is* a sad story.

It seems like you're feeling the sadness of the story, and that's okay. Sometimes stories *do* make us feel things.

Now, before Midas couldn't eat and before... before his daughter... do you remember if anyone *warned* him about the golden touch? Someone tried to tell him it might not be such a good idea. Can you remember who that was? It's alright if you don't! We can think about it together. Maybe knowing *who* warned him will help us understand *why* it was a bad idea.

(Sniffling quietly, wipes eyes with the back of their hand)

... Dionysus? (looks up, a question in their eyes) The... the wine guy? (uses a more complex word, proud for a moment) He... he said it wasn't good? But... (brows furrow in confusion) But Midas didn't listen? Why didn't he listen? (anxious again, chews on fingernail) Was he... was he silly?

You're doing *so* well, and it's great that you remembered Dionysus and that Midas didn't listen to him. It sounds like you're really connecting with the story! Before we talk more about *why* Midas didn't listen, could you try to tell me *everything* you remember about the story, just in your own words? Don't worry about getting it perfect, just tell me what you remember from the beginning to the end. It will help us put all the pieces together!

(Takes a deep breath, looks away, trying to organize thoughts)

Okay... (pauses) King Midas... he helped... (struggles to remember the word) ...a Satyr. And then... the wine god, Dionysus, said he could have a wish. And Midas... (voice gets softer) ...he wished for everything to turn to gold. Dionysus said no! But he did it anyway. (eyes well up again)

And then... (voice cracks) ...he touched everything and it turned to gold! And he was happy... for a little bit. But then he was hungry. And... and he couldn't eat. And then his daughter... (sobs quietly) ...turned into gold too! And... and he was sad. (looks at the teacher, pleadingly) It was a bad wish! (sniffles) He should have listened!

You’ve done an amazing job remembering the whole story, and it's okay to feel sad about it. It *was* a bad wish, and you're right, he should have listened. You really understood the story and how Midas felt. I'm so proud of you for working so hard! Have a good day, and I'll see you next time!

This will take 2 utterances.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's quite a fascinating tale, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most?

(Looks down, fidgeting with my pencil)

Uh... (long pause) the gold part.

Yes, the gold is a key part! It's pretty amazing, isn't it, this idea of turning things to gold? Can you tell me one thing about the gold that you found interesting? It doesn't have to be a big thing, just anything that popped into your head.

(Thinking, chews on my pencil eraser)

...That... that the food turned to gold? (Looks up quickly, then down again)

That's a great observation! The food turning to gold *is* a pretty important detail. It shows us that Midas' wish wasn't as wonderful as he thought it would be, doesn't it? What do you think might have been going through his head when he realised he couldn't eat?

(Looks away, shrugs)

...Uh... sad? (Quietly) Because... no food?

You got it exactly right! Sad is definitely a big part of it. And you're spot on – because there was no food! You're really understanding this. Now, thinking about *why* he's sad... can you think of another word, maybe something a bit stronger than "sad," to describe how Midas might have felt when his food turned to gold? It's okay if you're not sure, just take a guess!

(Thinking hard, wrinkles forehead)

...Uh... (hesitates) ...frus...frustrated? 'Cause he wanted to eat, but he... couldn't? (Looks up, hopeful)

Frustrated is a *fantastic* word! It fits perfectly. You're doing so well at understanding how Midas felt! Now, just to make sure we've got it all clear, can you tell me in your own words what we've talked about so far regarding the story, focusing on how Midas felt about the golden touch?

(Looks down at my hands, tracing the lines on my palm. Mumbles)

...He wanted gold... everything gold... (pause) ...Then... food gold... (longer pause) ...he's... frustrated. (Looks up, a little confused) Is 'frustrated' like... really, really sad?

Yes, "frustrated" can be like "really, really sad," especially when you're trying to do something important, like eat, and you just... can't! You've got the main idea of the story, and you explained it so well! Well done! I think you have a great understanding of the story. Have a great day!

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas! It's a bit of a sad story, isn't it? What part of the story made you feel the saddest?

(Fidgets with my hands, looks down at my shoes)

Uh... (long pause)... when... uh... (stuttering) ...when the... uh... the girl... turned gold. (Looks away, nervously)
That *is* a sad part. It's okay to feel that way. Can you tell me one thing you noticed about *how* the story describes her turning to gold?

(Thinking hard, bites lip)

...Uh... It... it said she... hugged him? (Peeks up at the teacher quickly, then looks back down)
That's right, she hugged him. You're doing great! Now, what do you think that hug tells us about how she felt about her father?

(Shrugs, voice barely a whisper)

...Uh... Liked him? (Looks at the floor, kicking a small stone) ...A lot?

Yes, she liked him a lot! You're really understanding this. It can be a bit upsetting to think about, so we can take a break if you like. But if you're okay to keep going, let's think about *why* the story tells us she hugged him *right* before she turned to gold. What does that timing tell us?

(Eyes widen a little, face scrunches up in concentration. Fidgets again.)

...Uh... (long pause)... Because... (stuttering) ...he was sad? (Looks up at the teacher with a worried expression) ...She wanted to make him... happy?

You've picked up on so much already, even the tricky parts! To make sure we've got everything clear, could you try to tell me everything you've worked out about the story so far, in your own words? Don't worry if it's not perfect, just try your best.

(Looks down at my hands, takes a deep breath, trembling slightly.)

...Uh... (very quiet voice)... King Midas... he helped someone... and got a wish... and wished for gold... (pauses, close to tears)... Then... everything turned gold... even food... (sniffs)... and his daughter... she hugged him... 'cause he was sad... and she turned gold too... (voice cracks) ...because... (long pause, struggling) ...the gold... was bad? (Looks up, eyes wide and pleading)

That's a really good summary, and it's okay to feel sad about it. You're absolutely right, the gold *was* bad, even though Midas thought it would be good at first. You've understood the story really well. Well done for working through it, even when it was upsetting! We're all done for today now, so have a good rest of your day and I'll see you next time.

dialogue: Okay, let's talk about the story of King Midas. It's quite an interesting one, isn't it? What part of the story stood out to you the most?
Uh... (looks away, fidgeting with my hands) The...the gold?
Yes, the gold! That's a great starting point. What about the gold do you find interesting or maybe a little strange? Don't worry, there are no wrong answers!
(Shrugs) Uh... everything turns...gold? (Looks down at my shoes)

That's right! Everything he touched turned to gold. That's quite a power, isn't it? Can you think of something that might be really great about having that power? Even one small thing? Take your time to think.
(Thinking hard, chewing on my lip) ...Uh... Toys? (Looks up quickly, then back down) Everything...gold toys?

Gold toys! That's a very creative idea! And you're right, *everything* he touched turned to gold. Now, that sounds pretty amazing, doesn't it? But what do you think might happen if *everything* you touched turned to gold, even things you didn't want to?
(Eyes widen a little, thinking) ...Uh... (Hesitates) ...Food? (Looks at you, then quickly looks away again)

You've had some really good ideas! You've thought about the fun of gold toys, but also the problem of food turning to gold. Can you put all those thoughts together and tell me in your own words what you think about the story so far?
(Stuttering, picking at a loose thread on my shirt) ...Uh... gold... good... but... (pauses, thinking hard)... not... good if... can't eat? (Looks up, a little more confident)

That's a great way to put it! Gold seems good at first, but it's not good if you can't eat. You've really understood the problem that King Midas faced. Well done! It's been great chatting with you today. Keep thinking about stories like this, okay? Goodbye!

dialogue: Hey there! That's a pretty wild story about King Midas, right? What part of the story stood out to you the most? Don't be shy, tell me what you really thought, even if it's a bit silly!

(Eyes widen, shifting in my seat, then blurting out, almost before the teacher finishes)

Gold, gold, GOLD! He turned EVERYTHING into gold! (Jumps up and down a little) Can you imagine? Like, my toys? GOLD! My cookies? GOLD! Everything SHINY! (Stops jumping, frowns) But...but then he couldn't eat. That's kinda dumb. Why would you wish for that if you couldn't eat? (Pokes at my desk)

Haha! Okay, you've got the Midas touch! (Gestures dramatically with my hands). So, tell me, Your Royal Goldness, you're standing in your throne room... EVERYTHING you see is GOLD! What's the *most* amazing, super-duper awesome thing about it? And... what's the *most* totally awful, makes-you-wanna-cry thing about it? Go on, paint me a picture with your words!

(Stands up, puffs out chest, looks around the imaginary throne room)

Okay, okay! The *most* awesome thing? (Points dramatically) My race car bed! GOLD! It would be SOOOO fast, even faster than Lily's new bike! And my LEGO castle? (Sniffs) GOLD! Nobody could break into it EVER! It would be the bestest castle EVER EVER EVER! (Sits down suddenly, scowls)

But... the most awful thing? (Looks down, kicks feet) Probably... (Stutters) ...probably if... if... my dog, Sparky, turned into gold. (Voice cracks) I couldn't pet him then! He'd be cold and hard and... and he couldn't lick my face! (Starts to tear up a little) That would be the WORST THING EVER! He couldn't even play fetch! (Wipes nose on sleeve) That Midas guy was really, really stupid.

(Softens voice, leans forward conspiratorially) Okay, Your Goldness, big question. Sparky's okay, promise! He's right here (gestures to imaginary dog). *But*, let's say Dionysus pops in, gives *you* a wish. Knowing what Midas went through, and knowing how much you love Sparky... what would you wish for *instead* of the golden touch? Think carefully! This is your chance to be a *smart* ruler, not a gold-crazy one! What would make *you* truly happy?

(Sniffs again, looks at the imaginary Sparky, hugs myself tightly)

Hmm... (Looks at the ceiling, taps chin with finger, muttering to myself). No gold, no gold... can't touch Sparky... hmm... (Suddenly brightens, claps hands) I know! I wish... I wish... that I could understand what Sparky is thinking ALL the time! (Looks at the teacher expectantly) Then I would know exactly what he wants, like if he needs to go potty, or if he wants a treat, or if he's scared of the vacuum cleaner! And then he'd be super happy and I'd be super happy and it would be the best wish ever! Way better than stupid gold! (Crosses arms, satisfied)

(Beaming, nods enthusiastically) You know what? That's an AMAZING wish! Way smarter than old Midas! (Gives a playful nudge). Okay, Super-Sparky-Communicator! Before our time's up, tell me EVERYTHING we've talked about with the Midas story. From the beginning to your awesome Sparky-wish! Give me the whole shebang! What did Midas do? What did he wish for? And what did *you* learn from his silly mistake?

(Sighs dramatically, slouches in chair)

Ugh, do I *have* to? (Looks away, fidgeting). Fine, fine. Midas was, like, a king, and he helped some… (trails off) some… what was it? (Looks at the teacher with wide, pleading eyes) I forgot! He helped someone... and then he got a wish! And he wished for gold, gold, GOLD! And everything he touched turned to gold, even his food! And then he couldn't eat and it was, like, a super bad wish! (Rubs eyes) And I learned that gold is stupid if you can't eat or play with your dog. (Looks up, brightening) And *I* wished I could talk to Sparky, so I could know what he wants! (Grins widely) Is that good enough? Can I go play now? (Starts reaching for backpack)

That's fantastic! You remembered all the important parts! You're totally right, gold is pretty useless if you can't share it with the people (and pups!) you love. You’ve been a super star today! Go on, off you go! Have a great time playing with Sparky – give him an extra hug from me!

And... and... everything! (Stands still, grinning)

Whoa, hold on there, gold-ifying master! That *would* be pretty epic for a little while! But let's think about this superpower for a sec. Wanna play a game? It's the "Midas Challenge"!

(Grinning) Okay, round one! You already noticed the food thing! *BAM!* One point for you! You realized he couldn't eat! Awesome job! So, food turns to gold... Is that *totally* awesome all the time? What's one not-so-awesome thing that could happen because of that? Think about King Midas... he's got a belly rumbling! What's he gonna do? Quick, quick, before the gold rush takes over! Tell me the problem!

(Jumps up and down)

Easy peasy! (Sticks tongue out) He's gonna be, like, super hungry! (Rubbing stomach) And grumpy! My tummy gets all rumbly and I get *so* grumpy! Then I yell at my sister! (Looks away, shuffling feet) But, uh... King Midas can't just go get a snack, can he? (Thinking, tapping chin) Because... (Eyes widen) ...everything he touches is gold! So, like, even if he grabbed a yummy cookie... (Makes a grabbing motion) ...it would turn into a gold cookie!

(Starts pacing again, getting excited)

So, he's gonna be hungry forever! Unless... unless... (Stops pacing suddenly) ...he can turn it *off*! Can he turn it off? (Looks expectantly at the teacher) If he can't, then that's a dumb power! (Crosses arms)

"Ding ding ding! Another point for the 'Hungry King' realization! You're totally right, that's a *major* downside! But you're onto something HUGE now! Can he turn it off? Hmmm... that's the million-dollar question! Let's make it worth a point!

Here's the deal: Imagine *you're* King Midas, and you're STAAAAARVING! What's your next move? What are you gonna try to do to fix this golden mess? Think like a king... but also think like a super-smart, problem-solving YOU! Quick, what's your plan to turn off the gold touch curse?"

(Sits down heavily, kicking legs)

Ugh, this is hard! (Stares at the ceiling) Okay, okay... If I was King Midas and I was super, super hungry (rubs stomach dramatically), and *everything* I touched turned to gold... First, I would yell! (Yells loudly) "I'M HUNGRY!"

(Lowers voice) Then... (Taps chin thoughtfully) Then I'd try *not* to touch anything. Like, maybe use a really, really long spoon! (Makes a reaching motion with an imaginary spoon) But then the spoon would turn to gold, too! (Groans loudly)

(Suddenly stands up, eyes wide)

Wait! I know! I'd find the guy who gave me the power! (Points finger) The wine guy! Dionysus! And I'd yell at *him*! (Screams) "Take it back! Take it back!" He's the one who did it, so he has to fix it! (Sits down again, satisfied) That's my plan! (Looks expectantly at the teacher, bouncing leg)

(Clapping hands enthusiastically)

"BOOM! Two points! One for the clever spoon idea (even if it *did* turn to gold!), and another HUGE point for tracking down Dionysus! That's *exactly* what a smart king would do! You are rocking this Midas Challenge!

(Leaning in conspiratorially, lowering voice)

"Okay, super-sleuth, you found Dionysus! But... here's the twist! Dionysus isn't *super* thrilled that you're yelling at him. He looks kind of annoyed. He says, 'Okay, Midas... you got your wish. Now you're complaining? Hmmm...' (Pauses for effect) He *might* be willing to help... *if* you can convince him you learned something! What do you think you did wrong? What lesson did Midas learn?"

(Scoffs, rolls eyes)

Learned something? (Picks at fingernails) He learned that gold is, like, *not* the most important thing? (Looks at the teacher, then quickly looks away) Duh! Everyone knows that! (Mumbles) Especially when you're hungry.

(Sighs dramatically)

He was being greedy! He wanted all the gold for himself! (Looks around the room) And now he can't even eat! (Points finger) That's what happens when you're greedy! You end up with a gold daughter and no lunch! (Crosses arms, pouting)

Alright, superstar! You've totally nailed the ending. Greed *definitely* bit Midas hard! Gold daughter, no lunch – you've painted a pretty clear picture of his mess! Before we wrap up this golden adventure, can you quickly zoom out and give me the super-short version? What *exactly* did Midas do, what went wrong, and what's the BIG lesson we learned? Let's hear your final, shiny summary!

(Stands up, puffing out chest)

Okay! Midas was, like, super greedy and wished for everything to turn to gold! (Holds up hands dramatically) Then he couldn't eat, and he turned his daughter into a gold statue! (Frowns) So, he learned that being greedy is bad! (Sits down, thumps the table) And that cookies are more important than gold! (Grins, then shrugs) I knew that already, though. (Looks around for something else to do.) Can we read another story now? Maybe one about superpowers that *don't* turn everything into gold? (Bites lip expectantly)

(Beaming, clapping hands again)

You absolutely crushed it! A shiny, golden A+ for that Midas recap! Super greedy, golden daughter, cookie > gold epiphany! You got the whole story, you got the lesson, and you even knew it all along! (Winks) You're a storytelling superhero! Sadly, it's time to go for now. Have an amazing rest of the day, and keep those awesome stories coming! I can't wait to hear what adventures we'll explore next time! Bye!

record.strategy_description:
Okay, let's use gamified learning and motivational encouragement.

**Implementation:** Turn the story analysis into a "Midas Challenge." Award points for identifying consequences of Midas's wish (e.g., "1 point for realizing he can't eat!"). Offer praise and excitement for each point earned ("Awesome job!").

**Utterances:** 2

record.summary: The student has identified the core problem of Midas's wish: his inability to eat. His body language is restless. He recognizes Midas is hungry and cannot consume anything due to the golden touch. He is now trying to find a solution to the problem by yelling at Dionysus to take the curse away.

The student enthusiastically summarized the story, focusing on Midas's golden touch and its immediate consequences like turning food and his daughter into gold. The student, initially excited, becomes frustrated by the limitations of the power. The student is restless, pacing, jumping, and often fidgeting but is able to identify the problem of greed as the cause.

The student summarized the story of Midas, focusing on the golden touch's consequences, like the inability to eat and turning his daughter to gold. They identified greed as Midas's downfall. The student displayed a range of body language: pacing, fidgeting, dramatic gestures and facial expressions, and shifts in posture reflecting their engagement and excitement.

dialogue: Hey there! That's quite a story about King Midas, isn't it? What's the first thing that popped into your head after hearing it? Don't be shy, there are no wrong answers!

(Runs ahead, almost bumping into the teacher) Gold! (grinning widely) He got lots and lots of gold! He touched things and *poof* gold! Shiny, shiny gold! (Sticks out tongue slightly) I want gold! (Looks away, starts fiddling with shoelaces) Um... he... he wanted it. He said he wanted it, right? (Shrugs, then starts to hum loudly to a tune only I know).

Whoa there, Speedy Gonzales! Slow down! Gold, gold, gold, you say? I get it! Me too! Imagine all the things Midas could turn to gold! Okay, close your eyes... if YOU had the golden touch, what's the *first* thing you'd turn into solid gold? A giant lollipop? Your shoes so you could zoom around even faster? Tell me, tell me! What's your gold dream?

(Eyes widen, jumps up and down) Lollipops! (Stops jumping suddenly, frowning) But... then I can't eat them! (Scowls) That's dumb! (Pokes teacher in the leg) So... no lollipops! (Crosses arms, looks away, then back to the teacher, speaking loudly) My... my bed! A gold bed! (Starts bouncing again) I would sleep on GOLD! (Suddenly stops, face crumples slightly) But... (Stuttering) w-would it be c-comfy? (Looks at the floor, kicks at an imaginary rock).

A gold bed, huh? Now THAT'S thinking big! (I mimic their bouncing with a little knee wiggle.) But you're right, would it be comfy? Hmm... maybe Midas could have turned some pillows into gold... then covered *those* in soft blankets? (I pause, tapping my chin dramatically.) Wait a minute! If he turned his blankets into gold, would *those* be comfy? This golden touch thing is trickier than it looks, isn't it? Maybe Midas didn't think it through! What else do you think Midas *should* have turned into gold? Something really, really awesome, but maybe something he wouldn't... you know... NEED?

(Scowls, picks at a loose thread on my shirt) I dunno. This is... (makes a face) ... hard. (Shrugs aggressively) Rocks? Turn rocks into gold! Then throw them! (Throws an imaginary rock, making a "pew" sound). Gold rocks! (Stops, looks thoughtful for a millisecond, then bursts out) NO! Then nobody could have rocks to, like, build stuff! (Starts pacing back and forth, muttering under breath) Rocks are... important... but gold is shiny... (Suddenly stops pacing, looks up with a panicked expression) Wait! Was Midas... was he a bad guy? (Eyes start to water).

Woah, slow down there, superstar! You're like a detective figuring out a super-complicated case! Rocks, beds, lollipops... comfy, not comfy... good, bad... Your brain is buzzing! Okay, okay, deep breath! Before we go any further, can you tell me *everything* you've figured out about the story so far? All your thoughts, even the confusing ones! Just... spill it all out! What do you know about Midas and his golden touch right now?

(Takes a shaky breath, wipes nose with sleeve) He... he wanted gold. (Looks at the floor, then back up nervously) He got a wish. From... from a god! (Voice gets louder and more agitated) He turned everything to gold! But... but he couldn't eat! (Almost shouts) And he turned his daughter into GOLD! (Starts to cry, clenching fists) That's... that's not nice! He's... (Stutters) he's a... a meanie! And gold... gold is... (voice trails off, whimpering slightly) ... maybe not so good? (Looks at teacher with wide, tearful eyes) Is he gonna be okay? Is his daughter okay?

Okay, okay, breathe with me. (I take a big, exaggerated breath in and out). You got it. You REALLY got it! Midas *thought* he wanted gold, but he didn't think about what it would *cost* him. You're right, turning his daughter into gold wasn't nice AT ALL. It was... (I search for the right word) ... a HUGE mistake. As for whether they'll be okay... well, that's the sad part of the story, isn't it? It shows us that sometimes, the things we *think* we want can actually hurt us the most. But hey, you figured out the most important part! You're a super smart cookie! Now, how about we put this story away for today, yeah? You’ve done an amazing job and deserve a break. See you later and try to have some fun.

record.strategy_description:
Okay, here's how we implement the playful role-play strategy with a high-extroversion student:

We'll use their excitement about gold as a springboard. I'll act as a fellow gold enthusiast, asking about *which* gold items Midas might like, prompting them to think beyond "shiny gold" and consider the consequences. This would likely take 1-2 utterances.

record.summary: The student is initially excited about Midas's golden touch, focusing on the gold's shininess and expressing a desire for it. They considered gold lollipops and a gold bed, but recognized the impracticalities. They suggested turning rocks to gold before realizing rocks are important. The student is physically restless, grinning, bouncing, fiddling, and pacing, but becomes subdued and worried when considering the consequences and Midas's morality, with eyes starting to water.

The student, initially excited about Midas's golden touch, focused on the immediate gratification of turning things to gold. They considered lollipops and a bed, but quickly realised the impracticalities. The student is clearly struggling with the concept, shown through fidgeting, pacing, and shifts in body language - from excited bouncing to scowling and tears. They've grasped that Midas received a wish, turned things to gold (including his daughter), and that this had negative consequences.

dialogue: Hey there, superstar! That's a pretty interesting story about King Midas, isn't it? What part of the story jumped out at you the most? I wanna hear *your* thoughts first!

(Running around the desk, almost bumping into the teacher) Yeah, yeah, King Midas! Gold, gold, gold! (Stops abruptly, looks at the teacher, arms crossed) He got lots of gold! That's the best part! He touched stuff and BAM! Gold! (Points finger like a gun)

Gold, gold, gold! You got it! High five! But hey, after all that "BAM!" gold... what *else* happened? I'm thinking... (eyes widen dramatically, whispering) What about lunchtime for King Midas, eh? Did he order pizza... or maybe a golden burger? *Could* he order pizza? What do you think happened then?

(Rolls eyes, scuffs shoe on the floor) Pizza? (Scoffs) Who cares about pizza! He had GOLD! (Pulls out a toy car from pocket and starts zooming it around on the desk, making engine noises). But... uh... (stops the car, looks at it) ...everything turned to gold, right? (Looks at the teacher, then back at the car) So... maybe he couldn't eat? Gold pizza is yucky! (Shrugs, starts zooming the car again, louder this time). Vroom! Vroom!

You are totally right! Gold pizza *is* yucky! Haha! Nice zooming, by the way! Okay, so King Midas is starting to figure out that maybe all this gold isn’t so great if he can’t even eat. What happened *after* he realized he couldn't eat? What's the next thing that happened in the story? You're doing awesome!

(Stops zooming the car, bangs it on the desk) Fine, fine! (Looks away, picks at a loose thread on shirt). His daughter... (mumbles) ...she hugged him... and then she was gold too. (Looks at the teacher with a blank stare). So?

Okay, okay, daughter turned to gold. BAM! You got it! See, you *do* remember! Nice BANGING of the car, by the way! (Quietly) Just maybe a *little* less banging, okay?

So, his daughter turned to gold... Now, here's a super-important question: How do you think King Midas felt *then*? Sad? Happy? Angry? Let's give him some "Feeling Points"! If he's a little sad, he gets one point. If he's REALLY sad, he gets FIVE points! What do you think? How many "Feeling Points" does King Midas get now that his daughter is a golden statue?

(Crosses arms again, looks at the ceiling) Five! (Says loudly and confidently) Five points! (Looks down at the car again, kicking it slightly with foot) Because... because he can't hug her anymore! (Mumbles) ...stupid gold... (Kicks the car harder).

FIVE POINTS! BOOM! You nailed it! Five BIG feeling points for King Midas! That's right, he can't hug her anymore - stupid gold, you said it! Okay, superstar, before we zoom off with that awesome car (less kicking, remember!), can you tell me, in your own super-duper words, everything that happened to King Midas and why he's now got FIVE feeling points? Let's hear the whole story, quick like a race car!

(Starts pacing back and forth) Okay, okay... so he helped some... some guy... (snaps fingers) ...a satyr! And then... (scratches head) ...Dionysus gave him a wish! He wanted gold! Everything he touched turned to gold! (Points dramatically) Food, tables, everything! But then... he couldn't eat! (Makes a gagging sound) Yucky gold food! And then his daughter... (voice gets quieter) ...she hugged him and she turned to gold too! (Stops pacing, looks down at shoes) So he got five points because he's sad he can't hug his daughter anymore. (Looks up at the teacher, fidgeting) Is that good enough? Can I play with my car now? Vroom?

VROOM! That's *perfect*, speedster! You zipped through that story like a champion racer! You got *all* the important parts, from the satyr to the super-sad, no-more-hugs ending. You totally understand why King Midas earned those five feeling points. High five! Now, go burn some rubber with that car! You earned it! See you next time for more stories and even MORE VROOM!

VROOM! That's *perfect*, speedster! You zipped through that story like a champion racer! You got *all* the important parts, from the satyr to the super-sad, no-more-hugs ending. You totally understand why King Midas earned those five feeling points. High five! Now, go burn some rubber with that car! You earned it! See you next time for more stories and even MORE VROOM!

record.strategy_description:
Okay, let's use a friendly tone and playful role-play to explore the story's details!

**Implementation:** I'll enthusiastically mirror the student's energy ("Gold, gold, gold!") and then playfully ask, "But what *else* happened after the 'BAM!' gold moment? What about lunchtime for King Midas, eh?".

This should take 1-2 utterances.

record.strategy: step-by-step scaffolding, gamified learning items, motivational encouragement
record.strategy_description:
Okay, let's break it down!

We'll use **step-by-step questioning:**

1.  "What happened *after* Midas couldn't eat?" (Encouragement: "Great thinking about the pizza!")
2.  "How did Midas feel then? Let's pretend we're giving out 'Feeling Points'!" (Gamification)

**Utterances:** 2

record.summary: The student, initially excited about King Midas getting gold, acknowledges that everything he touched turned to gold, including his food. They reluctantly admit he couldn't eat. They recall his daughter turning to gold after hugging him. The student displays fidgety body language, including running around, playing with a toy car, and avoiding eye contact.

The student recalls Midas turning things to gold. They understand Midas couldn't eat and his daughter turned to gold. They initially focused on the "gold" aspect, dismissing the consequences. Their body language shifts from excited movement to fidgeting, disinterest, and mild frustration, indicated by playing with a toy car, rolling eyes, kicking and banging the toy, and mumbling. Finally, the student awards Midas "five feeling points" for sadness.

The student summarised that Midas wished for a golden touch, turning food and his daughter into gold. They understand he received 'five feeling points' due to sadness. The student was restless, zooming a toy car and exhibiting frustration through fidgeting and louder car noises and kicking the car when speaking of the daughter.

dialogue: Okay, so we've read the story of King Midas. What's the first thing that pops into your head after hearing it? Don't worry about being right or wrong, just tell me what you're thinking.
(Looks down at my hands, fidgeting) Uh... gold. (shrugs) Everything...gold.

Gold is definitely a big part of the story! Can you remember *why* Midas wanted everything to turn to gold in the first place? What did he *want* the gold for? Just a little hint: was he thinking of anyone other than himself?

(Eyes dart around the room, then back to the teacher, nervously) He... he wanted... (Stuttering) W-wasn't... wasn't for anyone else. Just... just him. Uh... 'cause he wanted it. (Looks away, picking at a loose thread on my pants) Rich?
Rich is good! He wanted to be rich. Why do *you* think he wanted to be rich? What do you think being rich would let him do?

(Thinking, tapping foot impatiently) ...Buy... stuff? (Looks up, a flicker of interest) Anything he wanted. Like... a giant candy mountain! (Frowns) But... uh... (trails off, distracted by a classmate shuffling papers).

A giant candy mountain! That *does* sound amazing. Okay, so Midas wanted to be rich so he could buy anything he wanted, just like your candy mountain. Now, the story tells us he started touching things and they turned to gold. What *happened* after everything he touched turned to gold? Take your time, what's the next thing that happened in the story?

(Sighs dramatically, slumping in chair) Uh... He got... hungry. (Pauses) And... and he couldn't... eat. (Frowns) Everything turned... hard. (Makes a gagging noise) Yuck. Gold food! (Starts humming softly to myself, then abruptly stops, remembering the teacher).

Okay, so, you've remembered lots of important things! Midas wanted to be super rich like he had a candy mountain. He got his wish, everything he touched turned to gold, and then he got hungry but couldn't eat. Can you tell me all of that again, but in your own words, as quickly as possible?

(Anxious fidgeting in seat) Uh... Okay, okay. (Takes a deep breath, then rushes the words) He wanted all the gold so he could have a candy mountain, and then he got it, but he couldn't eat 'cause the food turned to gold and it was yucky! (Looks at the teacher with wide, slightly panicked eyes) Did I... did I do it right?

You absolutely did it right! You remembered all the important parts. See, you *do* know the story really well. I'm really proud of you for working through that, even when it felt a bit tricky. Have a great day!

They understand Midas wanted to be rich to buy things, but struggles to articulate further. The student displays nervous body language, like fidgeting, avoiding eye contact, and getting easily distracted.

The student recalls gold being central to the Midas story and identifies Midas's selfish desire for wealth to buy anything, like a "giant candy mountain." They remember Midas becoming hungry but unable to eat due to everything turning to gold. The student is fidgety, avoids eye contact, and seems distracted, but shows brief interest when discussing the candy mountain.

They remember him gaining the golden touch and subsequently being unable to eat due to his food turning to gold. dialogue: Okay, so we read the story of King Midas. What part of the story really grabbed your attention? What made you think, "Wow, that's interesting!"?
Uh... (shrugs, looks away) the... uh... the gold part.
That's cool! The gold part *is* pretty amazing, isn't it? What did you think about all that gold? Did you imagine what it looked like? Maybe shiny and bright?
...Shiny. (nods slowly, picks at a loose thread on my shirt)
Shiny gold! Awesome. What kind of things do you think he turned gold first?
...Table? (shrugs) I dunno. (looks around the room, disinterested)

You're right, shiny gold *is* pretty cool. And "table" is a great idea! Maybe it *was* a table! If *you* had the golden touch, what's the first small thing you might turn gold, just to see what it was like?
(thinking, chews on fingernail) ...My...pencil? (looks at my pencil on the desk, then back up, a flicker of interest in my eyes)
A golden pencil! Excellent choice. Would you write with it, or just look at it sparkle?
Write... I guess. (looks at the teacher, then back at the pencil, thinking hard) If...if it worked.
If the golden pencil *did* work, what colour ink would it use?
(confidently) Gold ink! ...Or maybe... rainbow ink? (a small smile, thinking beyond the obvious)

Rainbow ink from a golden pencil! That's wonderfully creative. Okay, so we've talked about gold, shiny things, and even rainbow ink. In your own words, can you tell me everything we've discussed about the story of King Midas so far? Just a quick recap.
(frowns, overwhelmed) Uh... Gold... (trails off, looks down at my hands) He touched...stuff... and it turned gold. And I'd turn my pencil gold. And... rainbow ink. (shrugs, unconcerned)

You've got the key points! Midas touched things, they turned gold, and we imagined a rainbow-inked golden pencil. That's a great start. I think we're ready to unpack the story a bit more next time. For now, have a good day, and keep those creative ideas flowing!

record.strategy_description:
Given the student's low extraversion and vague response, I'll use motivational encouragement to draw out their thoughts on the "gold part".

**Implementation:** I will gently prompt them to elaborate on *why* the gold part interested them, focusing on positive aspects like visual appeal or fantastical elements.

**Utterances:** This will take 2 utterances.

Okay, for a student with low extraversion, motivational encouragement means building on their brief responses with positive reinforcement and open-ended, low-pressure follow-ups. We can say:

"Shiny gold! Awesome. What kind of things do you think he turned gold first?"

This should take 1 utterance, as it is simple and directly related to the student's interest.

record.summary: The student is disengaged, indicated by shrugging, looking away, and picking at a thread. They acknowledge the "gold part" was interesting and "shiny," suggesting a basic understanding of Midas's wish. However, they struggle to elaborate, offering "table" hesitantly and expressing disinterest in speculating further.
record.strategy_description:
Okay, here's how to use motivational encouragement to get the student describing the scene:

**Strategy Implementation:** Focus on specific details. Praise any effort, even small ones. Ask questions that require minimal verbal output. Example: "Did the gold feel heavy, do you think?" Acknowledge the student's responses positively. (2 utterances)

record.summary: The student found the "gold part" interesting, specifically its shininess. They suggested Midas turned a table gold and, considering it, said they'd turn their pencil gold if they had the chance. The student initially seemed disinterested, looking away and shrugging, but showed a flicker of interest when asked about their own golden touch.

The student found the "gold part" interesting and imagined it as shiny. They guessed Midas turned a table gold first and, if they had the power, would turn their pencil gold. The student initially showed disinterest (shrugging, looking away, picking at thread) but perked up slightly at the pencil idea.

The student focused on the "gold part" of the Midas story. They described the gold as "shiny". Initially disinterested (shrugging, avoiding eye contact, picking at clothes), the student showed more engagement when considering turning their pencil to gold and contemplating its use, even suggesting rainbow ink.

The student focused on the gold aspect of the Midas story, agreeing it was shiny. They suggested a table and then their own pencil as initial gold-touched items, even imagining rainbow ink. The student appears disengaged, demonstrated by shrugging, avoiding eye contact, and fidgeting. They struggle to summarise the discussion.

dialogue: Okay, so we read the story of King Midas. What's the first thing that comes to your mind when you think about what happened to him? Don't worry about being right or wrong, just tell me what you're feeling or thinking.
Uh... (looks down, fidgeting with hands). Gold... too much gold...

Too much gold, that *does* sound overwhelming. It's okay to feel a bit lost in the story; it has a lot going on!

Let's try to think about just one small part of the story for now. Think about Midas's face... What do you think he's feeling right at the moment when his daughter turns to gold?
(Shrugs, avoids eye contact) ...Sad? Uh... mad? (Stutters) I... I dunno. (looks away)

It's completely understandable to feel unsure. It *is* a sad and shocking moment! "Sad" and "mad" are great words to start with.

Let's just think about "sad" for a moment. Can you think of a time you felt really, really sad? It's okay if you don't want to share the reason, just think about *how* your body felt when you were sad. Did your tummy feel a bit tight? Did you maybe want to cry?
(Thinking, chewing on the end of a pencil) ...Uh... yeah. Tummy hurt... (mumbles) Wanna cry...

That's it! You're doing great! Really focusing on what your body feels like when you're sad is a super important clue. Now, imagine Midas. His *daughter*, someone he loves very much, suddenly turns into a gold statue. Do you think his tummy might hurt too? Do you think he might want to cry?
(Nods slowly, still looking down) ...Yeah. More hurt... more cry...

Okay, you're doing so well! You've really thought hard about how Midas might have felt. Now, just to make sure we've got it all clear, can you tell me, in your own words, everything we've talked about so far about the story? What happened, and how did Midas feel about it? Just a quick summary.
(Sighs, picks at a loose thread on shirt) Uh... he... he got gold touch. (Stutters) Everything gold... then daughter gold... he sad. (Looks up briefly, then back down) Tummy hurt... wanna cry...

You did it! You told the whole story, step by step, and you even explained how Midas felt. That's fantastic! Remember, even when things feel a little tough, you can work through them. I'm so proud of you. See you next time!

Okay, with high neuroticism, we'll use motivational encouragement and step-by-step scaffolding.

**Implementation:** Acknowledge their feeling ("Too much gold, that sounds overwhelming"). Then, break down the task: "Let's focus on one small part – Midas's face. What do you think he's feeling right when his daughter turns gold?" I think this would take 2 utterances.

record.summary: The student is struggling to grasp Midas' emotions. They initially associate the story with "too much gold" and later suggest Midas might feel "sad" or "mad" when his daughter turns to gold. The student appears uncomfortable, fidgeting, avoiding eye contact, and mumbling. The teacher prompts them to connect the story to personal experiences of sadness.

The student has identified "too much gold" as overwhelming and suggests Midas felt "sad" and "mad" when his daughter turned to gold. They relate sadness to physical sensations like a tummy ache and crying. The student is hesitant, avoids eye contact, fidgets, and stutters, suggesting discomfort or uncertainty.

The student has summarised that Midas got the golden touch, everything turned to gold, including his daughter, and he became sad, with a stomach ache and the feeling of wanting to cry. The student displays a lack of confidence, avoiding eye contact, fidgeting, stuttering, and looking down.

dialogue: Okay, so we've read the story of King Midas. What's the first thing that comes to your mind when you think about what happened?
That's a great start! Gold is definitely a key element. Can you tell me anything *else* that stood out about the gold in the story?
That's an interesting point about the shininess! What *effect* did that shininess have on Midas, do you think?
(Stares blankly) Uh...dunno. (Picks at a loose thread on his shirt)

Okay, "dunno" is alright! Let's think about it differently. You said it was shiny, right? And shiny things can be... pretty cool, yes? What do you think Midas thought about having shiny gold EVERYWHERE? Maybe he thought it was... amazing? What's a word for that? Just try! It doesn't have to be perfect.

"Good" is a start! Now, let's put it all together. You said gold is shiny, and Midas probably thought it was "good" to have everything turn to gold. Can you tell me in your own words, just quickly, what has happened in the story so far, based on those ideas? What did Midas do, and what did he think about it? Just a short version!
(Grumbling) He... touched stuff. And it was... good... 'cause... shiny. (Looks down, avoids eye contact).

Okay, that's a good start! You've got the main idea: Midas touched things and he thought it was "good" because they turned shiny. That's the beginning of the story. Remember that Midas eventually realises having everything turn to gold wasn't so good. Maybe next time we can talk about why it wasn't good. Have a good day!
